{"uri": "8181821500", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "11:47:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T11:47:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T11:47:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/pep-guardiola-phil-foden-england-29367725", "title": "Pep Guardiola's drastic change for Phil Foden might solve England's problems", "body": "Gareth Southgate has a Phil Foden headache at Euro 2024 after the Manchester City talisman's non-existent display against Serbia, but Pep Guardiola previously identified a potential solution\n\nPep Guardiola has already offered a bold tactical solution to England's Phil Foden problems.\n\nGareth Southgate's men secured all three points in their Euro 2024 Group C opener against Serbia on Sunday, winning 1-0 thanks to an early Jude Bellingham header. But it was far from a vintage performance as England ceded control in the second half and allowed Serbia to grow into the game, grinding out a slim victory thanks to a solid defensive and goalkeeping display.\n\nThere was plenty of scrutiny post-match as viewers sought to identify the Three Lions' shortcomings, with Foden's performance - drifting in from the left flank - receiving much criticism. The Manchester City star and Premier League Player of the Year was anonymous for large parts of the game and failed to have any kind of impact without an overlapping left-back and occupying the same space as Harry Kane and Bellingham.\n\nREAD MORE: Man United boss Erik ten Hag slams Gareth Southgate 'vision' after England Euro display\n\nREAD MORE: Phil Foden's seven word message is perfect reply to Cesc Fabregas 'step up' criticism\n\nIt gave way to critics calling for him to be dropped against Denmark on Thursday, while others blamed Southgate for not utilising him in a central-attacking midfield position. However, City manager and tactical genius Guardiola provided another alternative on how to utilise Foden back in 2023.\n\nHaving yet to deploy Foden there in his career, Guardiola claimed the midfielder has the potential to flourish in a deeper role. That is despite the 24-year-old scoring 27 goals last season and largely being seen as an attacker, either through the middle or on the wings.\n\n\"When Phil plays as a right-winger, he can do it,\" said Guardiola. \"In the beginning when he played as a left-winger, he played well. In the middle he can play right, left, in the pockets - no problem.\n\n\"What I would like in the end is that he plays as a holding midfielder, or one of two holding midfielders. For that, he needs to understand the game as a whole, in everything, not just 'me'.\n\n\"But at the same time, he has this instinct, natural, like the big talents, in the final third. I'm not going to stop him. I'm not going to step in and say, 'Don't do that!' Because he's unique.\"\n\nDiscussing the prospect of Foden moving further back in midfield, Guardiola added: \"Sometimes it is the step one has to gain as a football player, playing in that position which carries some duties for the team.\"\n\nThe Spaniard's words at the time caused a stir due to Foden's guile, final ball and eye for goal being more suited to an attacking role. Yet similarly technical players such as Bernardo Silva, Xavi Hernandez, Santi Cazorla, Andres Iniesta and even Luka Modric have flourished by dropping deeper in the past, becoming integral to build-up play in the second phase of the attack.\n\nIt is important to note that Guardiola was likely offering his thoughts in terms of Foden later on in his career, when his pace declines and he has gained enough tactical knowledge to successfully play deeper. And Foden himself even revealed early on in the season that his favourite position is in the No.10 role, currently occupied by star man Bellingham for England.\n\nBut a player with his passing ability and press resistance playing alongside Declan Rice in the double pivot may kill two birds with one stone for Southgate - not having to drop one of his most talented players while solving the midfield problem.\n\nSouthgate experimented by playing Trent Alexander-Arnold, who primarily figures at right-back for Liverpool, in the middle against Serbia. His interception was crucial in the build-up to the goal - but he clearly lacked the legs and spatial awareness under pressure to become England's very own Toni Kroos, as his advocates had hypothesised.\n\nFoden's midfield experience could make him just that - though Kobbie Mainoo, Adam Wharton and Conor Gallagher remain ahead of him in the current pecking order for that role. Meanwhile, other more natural options for Southgate on the left wing include Anthony Gordon and Eberechi Eze.\n\nSpain's 2010 World Cup-winning midfielder Cesc Fabregas argued that getting the best out of Foden is not down to the manager but the player's desire and mentality himself during his punditry for the BBC. Whether Southgate decides to drop him, play him in a different position, or the Stockport man finally decides to rise up to the occasion at international level, England's Foden dilemma must be solved {"uri": "8185565535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:26:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:26:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:25:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/28597864/england-denmark-kane-tactics-change-foden-shine-euro-2024/", "title": "England shouldn't panic about Kane but MUST change to make Foden shine v Denmark", "body": "FEW nations, if any, match England when it comes to self criticism.\n\nThe 1-0 win over Serbia would have been cause for celebration for many, but instead it only seemed to raise further questions against the Three Lions' credentials of winning Euro 2024.\n\nA dominant opening 25 minutes gave way to a sluggish affair that saw Gareth Southgate's side struggle for control of the match and dangerously teeter towards conceding.\n\nThe Three Lions will come into the match looking to get six points out of six and secure a route into the knockout stages from Group C.\n\nDenmark will not be easy opponents, and their 3-5-2 system with powerful and quick forward players in Jonas Wind and Rasmus Hojlund and the creativity of Christian Eriksen behind them will cause some problems.\n\nIn this preview though we will concentrate on the lessons that Southgate may have learned from England's opening match against Serbia.\n\nDespite the emergence of Bellingham as a superstar on the world stage, Kane remains the talisman for the English national team.\n\nDespite the narrative surrounding the game that Kane barely touched the ball, he was in fact performing his role perfectly.\n\nWhile previously we have seen Kane drop into deeper to link the play with the midfield, his role in this England team is different and he is being asked to remain high to pin opposition defenders deep.\n\nThis pinning of the opposition central defenders is intended to create space between their defence and their midfield that can be exploited by the likes of Bellingham and Foden.\n\nIn this setup we are seeing Kane play a very specific role, but the fact he is not looking to drop in to get the ball and play long-range passing does not mean that his performance has dropped off.\n\nIndeed, his movement and positioning were effective against Serbia as he forced them to defend in a deeper line than they would have wanted to.\n\nThis created the space for the likes of Bellingham, Foden and Alexander-Arnold to occupy in the final third.\n\nBy pushing higher and maintaining this high position, we saw Kane create the platform for England's more creative players to occupy and hurt the Serbians with their movement through the lines.\n\nIt is also worth bearing in mind that had Kane's header in the 76th minute found the net and not been touched on to the crossbar then the narrative may have been very different.\n\nYes, yes he should. While it is fair to say Foden did not have his best match against Serbia we have to remember his outstanding performances for Manchester City last season.\n\nWhile Foden may not be at his best when asked to play from the left in a rigid system, it is worth noting that he played a different role to Bukayo Saka played on the right wing.\n\nWhile Sake stayed wide and looked to isolate defenders 1v1 on the wing, we saw Foden drift around the pitch in and out of pockets of space and not stay wide.\n\nPart of the issues Foden had in the match was down to the fact that he was trying to come inside and occupy the same spaces that Bellingham was taking up in central spaces.\n\nFoden wanted to receive in these areas, but having another player, like Bellingham, also spaced centrally meant that it was too crowded.\n\nAt Real Madrid, Bellingham often rotates outside to fill space on the left side of the attack as Vinicius Junior comes inside, but he typically stayed central in the final third against Serbia.\n\nSo, how do England and Southgate solve these issues to get the best out of Foden?\n\nWe believe adjusting the shape to have Bellingham starting from a deeper position, as the number 8 beside Declan Rice, and Foden then playing centrally as the 10 would be more effective in terms of finding the combinations and the angles to play through in the central areas.\n\nThis would also allow Southgate to use a more direct winger on the left side to stretch the pitch and create space centrally for their best players.\n\nIf Foden does play on the left side against Denmark then he will have to stay slightly wider, at the very least in the channels, in order to find the space to play.\n\nWhile England came into the tournament with fans and pundits alike praising their attacking options, there was real concern about the squad from a defensive perspective.\n\nWhile long-term Southgate favourite Harry Maguire was left out of the final squad there was a question mark as to who would start as the left-sided central defender in their back four?\n\nIn the end, Southgate decided to go with Crystal Palace star Marc Guehi, and the 23-year-old defender barely put a foot wrong.\n\nIn possession, he was safe and secure but also displayed the ability to progress the ball through the lines.\n\nDefensively he was solid as he dealt with the threat of the dangerous Serbian forwards.\n\nJuventus ace Dusan Vlahovic, in particular, looked to play on Guehi's side of the pitch.\n\nBut we saw the defender play effectively whether he was defending tight or in space as he stopped Vlahovic from receiving the ball in dangerous positions.\n\nAnd this was key in helping earn a clean sheet.\n\nKeeping the partnership of John Stones and Guehi at the centre of the defence might be one of the keys for England if they are to be successful in this tournament.\n\nOf course, different opponents will require different remedies.\n\nDespite only coming out of their opening group stage game against Slovenia with one point, Denmark will still be difficult opposition for England.\n\nTheir strikers, Wind and Hojlund, are both over 6ft with pace and power and the ability to run in behind the defensive line.\n\nThey have experience and technical quality throughout their squad and they will have studied the Serbia match to understand the threat England pose.\n\nThe key for England will be in finding ways to apply pressure to the Danish build-up.\n\nThe likes of Foden, Saka and Bellingham will have to be ready to join Kane in pressing high against the three-man Danish backline to prevent them from building their attack.\n\nAt the end of the day, England are the only side in Group C to come through the opening round of fixtures with three points and they have put themselves in the driving seat to secure qualification.\n\nBeating Denmark will see England through to the knockout stages, where the margins grow even finer.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tony_robertson@thesun.co.uk", "name": "Tony Robertson", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186782413", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:07:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:07:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:06:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/sports/football/england-coach-southgate-backs-phil-foden-ahead-of-denmark-clash-in-euro-202420240620153150/", "title": "England coach Southgate backs Phil Foden ahead of Denmark clash in Euro 2024", "body": "New Delhi [India], June 20 (ANI): England head coach Gareth Southgate backed Phil Foden and stated that he is aware that fans want to see Foden's \"sexy\" side of the game ahead of their clash against Denmark in the ongoing Euro 2024.\n\nFoden dazzled around defenders and enjoyed a prolific season in front of the goal. The 24-year-old netted 19 goals and registered eight assists, which helped Manchester City lift their fourth consecutive Premier League title. The Blues became the first team to achieve the feat.\n\nAfter enjoying a purple patch with the Premier League champions, the spotlight fell on Foden, with fans expecting the youngster to deliver for the Three Lions as well.\n\nDuring the tournament opener against Serbia, England clinched a 1-0 victory but Foden didn't deliver just like he did for the Premier League champions.\n\nAhead of their clash against Denmark, Southgate praised Foden for his performance against Serbia.\n\n\"I thought Phil did an incredible job for the team on Sunday. You know, sometimes the bits with the ball are obvious and they catch the eye, but the amount of ground he covered, the angles of pressing, the filling in for people who were further forward,\" Southgate said, as quoted from Sky Sports.\n\n\"I thought without Phil's contribution without the ball - and I know that's not the sexy bit and everybody wants to see him on the ball - I don't think we win the game. So then later in the game, when we needed somebody to retain the ball and take the pressure, I thought he did that really well for us,\" he added.\n\nSouthgate went on to point out the difference for Foden when he plays for Manchester City and England. The English manager pointed out familiarity and adaptation as the two factors that lead to different performances for both teams.\n\n\"I think Phil has obviously set an incredibly high bar at Manchester City, where he knows exactly where every player is going to be every time he picks the ball up. With us, we're always having to adapt to different team-mates, different runs they make and there is an adaptation with that,\" Southgate remarked. {"uri": "8181653891", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "09:58:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T09:58:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T09:56:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/euro-2024-palmer-southgate-england-33045552", "title": "Cesc Fabregas' take on Cole Palmer's 0 minutes for England makes perfect sense", "body": "Cesc Fabregas wasn't impressed by Cole Palmer's absence as England edged out Serbia\n\nCole Palmer's omission from England's Euro 2024 1-0 win over Serbia has gone down badly with Cesc Fabregas.\n\nThe Chelsea playmaker was an unused substitute in Gelsenkirchen as Gareth Southgate's side grinded out a tense tournament-opener in Group C. The Three Lions are top of the pool after their opening match but struggled to keep control after Jude Bellingham's early opener.\n\nFabregas, 37, was a guest during the BBC's coverage of the clash and passed judgement over Southgate's tactics. Namely, the Spaniard focused on the midfield and was surprised to see Palmer - who was named Premier League Young Player of the Season last term - fail to even make his way off the bench.\n\n\"If you send the message in putting in a defensive midfielder or an extra defender to cover the result, you will as a player feel it,\" said the guest pundit. \"Mentally you start going back, dropping more. But instead if you put an offensive player, Palmer let's say, up the pitch and controlling the ball in the final third, I think the players get so much more comfortable.\"\n\nSouthgate used only three of his five permitted substitutes on Sunday, with Conor Gallagher the first to join the fray as a replacement for Trent Alexander-Arnold in the 69th minute. Jarrod Bowen and Kobbie Mainoo then came on for Bukayo Saka and Bellingham, respectively.\n\nFabregas interpreted those changes as too defensively minded, and it showed in the game's momentum. England had five shots at goal in all against Serbia, but only one of those came in the final 20 minutes, while four of the opposition's six attempts materialised in that same span.\n\nFabregas also picked out Manchester City marvel Phil Foden for not doing enough on the night, adding: \"It's about do you want it enough to make a difference and hold the ball for your team? Do you want to make things happen? Do you enjoy to get the ball under pressure?\n\n\"They allowed them to have the ball when they were deep once in the second half, straight away, when they started to get pressed a little bit more, we started to see Foden hitting the ball without looking 40 yards.\"\n\nHe then compared the Premier League Player of the Season with past Barcelona team-mates, calling on Foden to do more for his country. \"You'll never see Xavi, [Andres] Iniesta, the top, top players in the last 15, 20, years, do that,\" Fabregas continued. \"You need to take this responsibility to grow.\n\n\"I think that the second half was a little bit underwhelming. I would say that is the right word. And I think players like Foden, they need to step up. This is the time for them to go into big tournaments with their country behind them.\"\n\nSouthgate & Co have three days to address any shortcomings before a crunch Group C clash against Denmark on Thursday. The Danes gave England some reprieve by drawing against lower-ranked Slovenia in their opening game, but defeat for the Three Lions could blow the group wide open.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8186840408", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:41:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:41:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:41:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/anthony-gordon-england-verdict-given-29388484", "title": "Anthony Gordon England verdict given as 'fearless' star backed to replace Foden", "body": "England manager Gareth Southgate has some selection dilemmas to resolve ahead of the Three Lions' crucial EURO 2024 clash with Denmark on Thursday evening, namely what he does with Phil Foden.\n\nThe Man City star may have won an abundance of major trophies, as well as being crowned the Premier League's Player of the Year this season, but he looked lost on England's left-hand side in their 1-0 win over Serbia on Sunday.\n\nFoden has enjoyed his best football as a 'number 10' with the Cityzens and the conundrum Southgate faces is whether he sticks with Foden on the left-hand side, moves him to his natural position and dropping Jude Bellingham into a deeper midfield role alongside Declan Rice, or whether he removes Foden from the starting XI altogether.\n\nREAD MORE: Sir Jim Ratcliffe makes 'unpopular' admission as Newcastle hold firm with Manchester United\n\nREAD MORE: Premier League 'changing' as Aston Villa chief makes 'really interesting' Newcastle claim\n\nNewcastle United winger Anthony Gordon was an unused substitute in Sunday's win but would be the natural replacement for Foden on the left-wing.\n\nGordon bagged 12 goals and 11 assists at club level this season and, as well as his ability to commit defenders and his work rate at both ends of the pitch, he is, crucially, a natural left-winger.\n\nShould Southgate opt to change Foden's role, Gordon is a likely bet to come into the starting XI, and there have been growing calls from a number of pundits to do just that.\n\nAs such, Chronicle Live has taken a look at the former England stars who would be keen to see Gordon earn a place in England's starting XI in Frankfurt this evening.\n\nAlan Shearer\n\nFormer Newcastle and England captain Alan Shearer has continually championed Gordon's cause and he feels he should come into the team at the expense of Liverpool star Trent Alexander-Arnold.\n\n\"What will he do next? I think he will make one or two changes,\" Shearer told the Rest is Football podcast.\n\n\"He might look at the Trent Alexander-Arnold situation. He might put Bellingham back alongside Rice and play Foden in the 10 and maybe put Anthony Gordon out wide [left].\"\n\nWayne Rooney\n\nSimilarly, former England captain Wayne Rooney believes Gordon is the 'right person' to start on the left-hand side of England's front three.\n\n\"I think since his move from Everton to Newcastle, obviously, I did a similar thing in moving to Manchester United, he got a bit of stick from the Evertonians. But he's settled down really well at Newcastle,\" Rooney told Channel 4\n\n\"He's brought great creativity, he's fearless with the ball and works hard. He brings a great balance to the team so, for me, he's the right person to start off that left.\"\n\nTheo Walcott\n\nTheo Walcott knows all too well about the demands of representing England as a winger in a major tournament and played alongside Gordon at Everton.\n\nAs such, the former Arsenal star has called for Gordon to come into the side as a direct replacement for Foden.\n\n\"I like Anthony Gordon. I've seen him up and personal,\" Walcott told Metro.\n\n\"I like the fact that he likes to go on the outside, not that standard, sort of inverted winger. He likes to challenge defenders, keep them guessing and I feel like you're going to need something different, and that's why he's there.\n\n\"He's there to provide something different for that squad. So, if I was going to change things, I'll probably put him in. I think there's a lot of debate about Phil Foden at this moment in time, who's best to play in those positions.\n\n\"Obviously, Bellingham for me is a stand out player which then means you lose a lot of Foden's qualities, so I would probably like to see Anthony Gordon if I'm being brutally honest. He's so exciting, he's fresh and he's fearless and I think you need that at international level.\"\n\nJamie O'Hara\n\nFormer Tottenham midfielder Jamie O'Hara agrees with Walcott and feels Foden 'has to be better' in an England shirt, regardless of what position he plays in.\n\n\"For me, you've got to start Anthony Gordon at left wing over Phil Foden,\" he told Grosvenor Sport.\n\n\"Gordon has had a great season for Newcastle - he works hard, he's direct and he makes things happen. He's good enough for this level and I would drop Phil Foden for him - as mad as that sounds.\n\n\"I think that in an England shirt Foden has to be better, whether he plays in his best position or out of position, he's a top player and he's good enough to make things happen no matter where he is on a football pitch.\n\n\"I do feel for him, you're asking him to play in an unnatural position on the opposite side to where he has played all season, but there were moments in the game where he was giving the ball away from simple passes and just wasn't making anything happen.\n\n\"You have to drop a player sometimes for the balance of the team, you're not going to drop Jude Bellingham from the 10 or Bukayo Saka from the right and he won't have Declan Rice sitting on his own, so he needs to be dropped and used as that impact sub off the bench like Marcus Rashford was at the World Cup, Foden needs to become that impact player and Gordon needs to start instead.\"\n\nAndy Cole\n\nHowever, Newcastle United legend Andy Cole does not feel Gordon deserves to start this evening and feels Chelsea's Cole Palmer would be a better alternative for Foden.\n\n\"No, not really,\" Cole told Betfred when asked if he feels Gordon should start against Denmark.\n\n\"I feel like everyone has been pushing for Gordon, before the end of the season, to go to the Euros, but when you look at England and what they have, you could have the same argument for Cole Palmer.\n\n\"When you end up with the goals that he's got, you could turn around and say that you've got to find a space for him, but then you could end up in an endless cycle of saying that England needs to find a place for Anthony Gordon, Cole Palmer, Bukayo Saka and Phil Foden. The list is endless.\n\n\"Everybody has got their own opinion about who they think should and shouldn't play, it's like the talk about Jack Grealish and Marcus Rashford not making the squad and what a mistake that is. It's all a matter of opinion.\n\n\"For example, look at how the media and people were talking about Saka the other day - everyone was saying that he was the one who deserved to miss out on the squad, then fast forward to Sunday night and with the way that he played, I think he's made a few people swallow their words as he proved to everyone, and himself, that he's worthy.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8184948807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:41:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:41:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:40:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/versatile-phil-foden-no-worry-083407824.html", "title": "Versatile Phil Foden is no worry for England as Gareth Southgate works on perfect formula", "body": "Five minutes gone at Wembley, and in the sunshine in front of a socially-distanced crowd, Phil Foden, hair dyed a la Paul Gascoigne on the same patch at Euro 96, shimmies inside a Croatian defender and curls towards the far corner to launch the summer he intends, even expects, to make his own.\n\nExcept rather than find that corner to give England their opening goal of Euro 2020, the ball comes back off the post. Instead, a little over an hour later, Raheem Sterling scores the game's winning goal and goes on to be the campaign's star.\n\nTo call the miss a sliding doors moment would perhaps be to offer it undue providence for what came next, but it is true that from that point Foden's tournament never really caught alight.\n\nHe started the next group game, the soggy 0-0 with Scotland, then lost his place through a complicated set of circumstances; a suspension risk, Mason Mount's Covid isolation and Bukayo Saka's breakthrough. Eventually, his tournament was ended by a training-ground injury that ruled him out even of a place on the bench for the final.\n\nAnd so it is understandable that already, after one peripheral outing against Serbia, there are fears that for English football's player of the year, this European Championship might spiral the same way; a shirt lost to, maybe, Anthony Gordon, an international career still selling itself short.\n\nTo ease those fears slightly, it is worth remembering that Foden's second major tournament, the World Cup in Qatar, followed the reverse trajectory: starting out of the side, finishing in it after excellent shows against Wales and Senegal along the way. Fair enough, he would not have made anyone's team of the tournament, but he made an impact. An even better player now, one quiet night in Gelsenkirchen is hardly grounds for a firm verdict that he cannot do the same at these Euros, at the very least.\n\nThe frustration is that that is not really enough for the best player in a country with designs on winning the thing; the nagging worry that, 35 caps (and only four goals) into his England career, it does not feel like the Foden of Manchester City is exactly on the cusp of being unlocked.\n\nAnd really, it is difficult to put your finger on exactly why. The most common theory has seen the old spoilsport Gareth Southgate accused of inhibiting a free spirit. But he has repeatedly stressed the licence Foden has to roam (arguably more than at City) and it was obvious in the opening half-hour against Serbia, when the 24-year-old popped up on all corners of the pitch.\n\nCesc Fabregas, in his largely excellent BBC analysis, wondered whether Foden might be a bit more Jude Bellingham (yes, and I'll just be a bit more Brad Pitt, I hear you cry) in visibly imposing himself on matches. But the City man is a different type of player, a different physique, a different personality.\n\nIn the search for something concrete, others have found comfort in the familiar idea that England's left wing is cursed ground. But Foden regularly excels there for City, scoring six goals in his six most recent starts in the position during the Premier League run-in.\n\nMore to the point, where else can he nominally play in this team, with Bellingham central and Saka so consistent in his output on the right?\n\nTrue, it might not be Foden's very best position, but international football is littered with players adjusting, doing jobs, and doing them well. Half of England's outfield starters against Serbia -- Kieran Trippier, Trent Alexander-Arnold, Declan Rice, Bellingham and Foden -- were not playing in their most familiar club role of the season just gone. Maybe that is a problem in itself, but it is the reality of building a team when passports dictate the talent pool and managers cannot buy custom fits.\n\nThe best players are adaptable and the paradox is that Foden is probably the most versatile of the lot, having had to take work wherever he could get it when trying to break into Pep Guardiola's plans in his teens. Even now, though an almost certain City starter, he is used in positional rotation, a horse for every course, ridden in different ways.\n\nThere is enough time left in this tournament, against Denmark on Thursday night and beyond, to believe Foden and Southgate, too, can find a formula that works, too.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, {"uri": "8181937750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "13:05:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T13:05:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T13:04:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.sportbible.com/football/england/england-euro-2024-jude-bellingham-phil-foden-582885-20240617", "title": "Fans noticed the moment Jude Bellingham 'ignored' Phil Foden in Serbia win", "body": "The displays of Jude Bellingham and Phil Foden in England's opening Euro 2024 game have caused mixed reviews.\n\nFans have spotted the moment where Jude Bellingham 'ignored' Phil Foden during England's win over Serbia.\n\nBellingham scored the only goal of the game and won the Man of the Match award as England got off to a winning start.\n\nThe 20-year-old headed home Bukayo Saka's deflected cross 13 minutes in and many loved the way in which the Real Madrid sensation played with such personality and arrogance.\n\nHe operated behind Harry Kane, with Foden playing off the left for drifting inside into pockets.\n\nThe Manchester City midfielder came in for criticism for struggling to affect the game.\n\nBut some supporters leapt to his defence and claimed that there was one instance where Bellingham elected against finding the the 24-year-old.\n\nIn the 67th minute, Bellingham had the ball down the left flank and toyed with Ivan Ilic.\n\nHe decided to beat the Torino man more than once and after going down the left, ended up delivering a cross that was easily gathered by Predrag Rajkovic.\n\nHowever, as many have pointed out on social media, Foden was on the edge of the box and screaming for the ball to be cut back.\n\nHe has produced stunning strikes from that type of range against the likes of Real Madrid, West Ham, Manchester United, Aston Villa and Everton.\n\nAnd Bellingham not spotting him in the position caused a stir amongst plenty of fans who felt analysis on his performance was unfair.\n\nOne wrote: \"What exactly was Foden called up to England for? That's my main question. If he can position himself and beg for the ball while being isolated like that and still not get it, what's the point of calling him up?\"\n\nA second opined: \"Jude was selfish on that spot.\"\n\nAnother said: \"3 men are free just outside the box. Why so many twist and turn and then a horrible cross? It's a team sport not an individual sport\n\nA fourth commented: \"This is why I refuse to believe Foden had a BAD GAME last night. This is just one of a hundred scenarios where he was available, but the players either didn't have the ability to find him or just didn't want to.\"\n\nA fifth fumed: \"Example of Jude doing too much. 95% brilliance but if you're looking for any improvement it's to know when to involve others in the game and to also play to their strengths.\"\n\nSouthgate, meanwhile was happy with Foden's contribution, stating that he \"popped up really well in the pockets\" and helped the team by \"holding the ball\" in key moments as they saw out the win.\n\nEngland return to action on Thursday when {"uri": "8182300666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "17:25:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T17:25:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T17:25:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.sportbible.com/football/england/england-euro-2024-gareth-southgate-serbia-denmark-236273-20240617", "title": "England's average positions from Euro 2024 opener shows huge problem for Gareth Southgate", "body": "Gareth Southgate has a big tactical issue ahead of England's next Euro 2024 game\n\nEngland kicked off their Euro 2024 campaign with a 1-0 win against Serbia but Gareth Southgate's tactics have been called into question.\n\nJude Bellingham's first half goal was enough to secure three points for the Three Lions who top group C after Denmark drew 1-1 with Slovenia earlier in the day.\n\nSouthgate opted to start Trent Alexander-Arnold at the base of the midfield alongside Declan Rice meaning Phil Foden was pushed to the left of the attacking midfield trio.\n\nQuestion marks were raised after a subdued second half showing at the Veltins Arena in Gelsenkirchen and Southgate has many tactical questions to ponder ahead of Thursday's game against Denmark.\n\nThe performance of Foden in particular was brought into focus after the win, with many fans suggesting the Manchester City man should be played down the middle in a similar position where he thrived under Pep Guardiola last season.\n\nIndeed, when looking at the average positions of the England players, it showcases the problem Southgate has in fitting the Premier League Player of the Year into his side.\n\nThe heatmap shows the 23-year-old in close vicinity to Bellingham who was operating as the central attacking midfielder, potentially limiting the impact he could have on games.\n\nSpeaking after the game, ex-Man City defender Micah Richards urged Southgate to find a way to bring the best out of Foden.\n\n\"The big talking point for me tonight was Phil Foden. I think the first 20 minutes he got into some really good positions. We need to find a way to get the best out of him.\n\n\"He wasn't involved. At Manchester City we obviously know it's choreographed with the system and the movements and all those sorts of things. But it makes me sad when I see a player of this quality just in and out of games.\"\n\nHe added: \"It's very difficult when Jude's got the freedom of the pitch and Phil is having to go from pressing out wide, to coming in midfield. The 24-year-old netted 19 goals and registered eight assists, which helped Manchester City lift their fourth consecutive Premier League title. The Blues became the first team to achieve the feat.\n\nEngland head coach Gareth Southgate backed Phil Foden and stated that he is aware that fans want to see Foden's \"sexy\" side of the game ahead of their clash against Denmark in the ongoing Euro 2024. Foden dazzled around defenders and enjoyed a prolific season in front of the goal. The 24-year-old netted 19 goals and registered eight assists, which helped Manchester City lift their fourth consecutive Premier League title. The Blues became the first team to achieve the feat.\n\nAfter enjoying a purple patch with the Premier League champions, the spotlight fell on Foden, with fans expecting the youngster to deliver for the Three Lions as well. During the tournament opener against Serbia, England clinched a 1-0 victory but Foden didn't deliver just like he did for the Premier League champions.\n\nAhead of their clash against Denmark, Southgate praised Foden for his performance against Serbia. \"I thought Phil did an incredible job for the team on Sunday. You know, sometimes the bits with the ball are obvious and they catch the eye, but the amount of ground he covered, the angles of pressing, the filling in for people who were further forward,\" Southgate said, as quoted from Sky Sports.\n\n\"I thought without Phil's contribution without the ball - and I know that's not the sexy bit and everybody wants to see him on the ball - I don't think we win the game. So then later in the game, when we needed somebody to retain the ball and take the pressure, I thought he did that really well for us,\" he added. Southgate went on to point out the difference for Foden when he plays for Manchester City and England. The English manager pointed out familiarity and adaptation as the two factors that lead to different performances for both teams.\n\n\"I think Phil has obviously set an incredibly high bar at Manchester City, where he knows exactly where every player is going to be every time he picks the ball up. With us, we're always having to adapt to different team-mates, different runs they make and there is an adaptation with that,\" Southgate remarked. {"uri": "8185427947", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:50:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:50:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:49:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/alan-shearer-names-his-england-11-to-play-denmark/", "title": "Alan Shearer has named his England XI to play Denmark", "body": "Highlights Shearer thinks Gareth Southgate should make changes to the England side that beat Serbia in their Euro 2024 opener. Phil Foden put in an under-fire performance against Serbia and Shearer believes he should move from the left-winger to the middle. Shearer thinks Trent Alexander-Arnold should drop out of the team, with Jude Bellingham moving into a more defensive position alongside Declan Rice.\n\nAlthough England's Euro 2024 campaign got off to a flying start against Serbia with a 1-0 victory, thus putting them at the top of Group C heading into the second round of fixtures, there were some issues that Gareth Southgate needs to sort ahead of their inevitably harder clash against Kasper Hjulmand's Denmark.\n\nFor instance: how to get the best out of Phil Foden? Former Arsenal and Chelsea man Cesc Fabregas recently insisted that it is down to the Stockport-born ace to grab a game of such magnitude by the horns, but the Three Lions chief could deploy him centrally to cater to his best attributes.\n\nSouthgate and Co have the chance to all-but confirm their progression to the knockout rounds with a win over the Danes - but the Premier League's all-time top goalscorer, Alan Shearer, wants to see a duo of tweaks to the side that clashed with Serbia.\n\nShearer Calls For Foden and Bellingham Change Thinks Man City man is deprived of best position Close\n\nSpeaking on BBC's coverage of the tournament alongside Fabregas, Frank Lampard and Gary Lineker, the former Newcastle United and Blackburn Rovers hitman suggested that Southgate could change the positions of two of the nation's star men, Foden and Jude Bellingham.\n\n\"I would go back to the team that I thought may have started in terms of playing [Anthony] Gordon on the left-hand side and I perhaps would have played [Jude] Bellingham alongside [Declan] Rice and then had [Phil] Foden in the 10 role. Keep Rice very much in that six position, yeah. Absolutely, that's what I would have done.\n\nTalking about Foden's struggles in England's curtain raiser, Shearer explained how having a right-footed Kieran Trippier at left-back may have limited what the Manchester City man was capable of on Sunday.\n\n\"Trippier is a really, really good full-back. But having a right-footed player at left-back, when he's receiving the ball, he's receiving the ball facing the goalkeeper rather than facing out to the left-hand side. So I don't think that actually helped Foden in that position either.\"\n\nThere's no doubting that Foden produced a worrying display against Serbia, but stationing him in the space behind Harry Kane, thus pushing Bellingham further back, would then rid the Los Blancos star of his favoured position. Running into the box to cause chaos and shoot on sight is Bellingham's bread and butter and that would be restricted with his compatriot moving infield.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic : Foden enjoyed his best-ever domestic return in 2023/24, notching 27 goals and 12 assists in 53 games across all competitions for Manchester City.\n\nShearer's England XI to Face Denmark Alexander-Arnold drops out\n\nAs expected, no changes have been made to England's back four because of a) the lack of options and b) how well they performed as a unit in Gelsenkirchen, while the ever-reliable Jordan Pickford keeps his spot between the sticks. For Shearer, though, moving Foden infield would be the way to go against Denmark.\n\nTaking over from Bellingham's role behind the leading talisman, Harry Kane, the Real Madrid ace would be forced to revert to a deeper role alongside Declan Rice, hence why Trent Alexander-Arnold is excluded from the starting XI. As alluded to, the latter would take on the majority of the defensive duties, allowing the former to be the difference maker in the final third, which was shown in abundance in England's opener.\n\nRelated Gareth Southgate Must Drop 2 Players and Name This England XI for Denmark Game\n\nA couple of players were not at their dazzling best during England's Euro 2024 curtain raiser.\n\nAble to provide England with an injection of pace on the left flank, Gordon's introduction could give Southgate and his men another outlet given that Marcus Rashford and Raheem Sterling - two experienced, darting run-making wingers - are not part of the squad. Alexander-Arnold will be tasked with partnering Rice at the base of midfield.\n\nBellingham should operate as England's number 10, flanked by Foden and Bukayo Saka, which will leave many supporters concerned by the lack of natural width on the left flank. Captain Harry Kane, who was another to struggle against Serbia, will spearhead England's attack.\n\nNewcastle United's Anthony Gordon is another option for Southgate wide left, should he look to make a change, but he was an unused substitute against Serbia as Foden, despite never really getting into the game, was given the full 90 minutes.\n\nJarrod Bowen saw minutes from the bench, replacing Saka with 15 minutes to go, while Mainoo came on for Bellingham late on as England sought to preserve their slender advantage.\n\nVictory against Denmark will put England through to the knockout stages {"uri": "8183078409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "07:01:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T07:01:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T07:00:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/06/18/terry-butcher-takes-aim-england-star-disappointing-serbia-showing-21051004/", "title": "Terry Butcher takes aim at England star after 'disappointing' Serbia showing", "body": "Former Three Lions captain Terry Butcher has called for Phil Foden to raise his game for England after his 'disappointing' performance in their Euro 2024 opener against Serbia.\n\nGareth Southgate's side got off to a winning start in their Group C opener on Sunday night with Jude Bellingham's bullet header early in the first-half enough to seal all three points.\n\nFoden by contrast endured a quiet night, failing to impose himself and cutting a frustrated figure at one stage, throwing his arms in the air after watching a move break down in the second-half.\n\nFoden, who played the full 90 minutes of the group opener, is coming off the back of a sublime season for Manchester City, often unplayable as he helped his side seal a fourth consecutive title having scored 27 times while laying on 12 assists.\n\nBut he is yet to consistently replicate that form in an England shirt, with Butcher, who won 77 caps for his country, admitting he would have been tempted to haul off the attacking midfielder against Serbia.\n\n'I was disappointed with Foden,' Butcher told Metro.co.uk courtesy of Free Bets.\n\n'That is not the Phil Foden we have seen all season at Manchester City. He came into that middle position too early and too often.\n\n'Kieran Trippier is the one who would give England the width on the left. Trippier is a good England defender, very tough but he is not naturally left footed like Luke Shaw or Ben Chilwell getting forward. We're limited down that side a bit.\n\n'Foden played the entire game, I probably would have taken him off earlier. He has had a long season, but he hasn't played for England the same way he has played for Man City. Sometimes we have seen glimpses of it and I am sure it will come and hopefully in this competition.\n\n'While everyone is talking about Bellingham and rightly so, we have other attacking talent who have been there and done it at club level. It is pretty formidable , that foursome [Bellingham, Bukayo Saka, Foden, Harry Kane].\n\n'It is a problem for other teams but we have got to make it a problem for them and give them the ball in key areas for them to work their magic.'\n\nWhile Bellingham was England's star man on the night, Marc Guehi also shone at the heart of defence alongside John Stones.\n\nFilling the void left by Harry Maguire who was not included in the final squad, the Crystal Palace defender turned in a composed performance - particularly in the first half where he completed every pass attempted and won every duel and tackle he was involved in against formidable centre forward opposition in Aleksandr Mitrovic and Dusan Vlahovic.\n\n'He won headers against some very experienced players. I was really pleased with his performance' Butcher said of the 23-year-old defender.\n\n;He knocked the ball around very well, to the point where you couldn't take which one was his strongest foot. His pace is also a big asset. But I loved the way he threaded the balls through to the midfield, into Bellingham, into Kane. The confidence to do that is great.'\n\nMORE : Didier Deschamps confirms the reason he made U-turn on Arsenal star William Saliba\n\nMORE : France superstar Kylian Mbappe could miss rest of Euro 2024 {"uri": "8185303120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:28:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:28:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:27:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://sportslens.com/news/ferdinand-foden-england-manchester-united-flop/", "title": "Ferdinand Tells Foden How He Can Improve England Fate, Likens Him To Manchester United Flop", "body": "Manchester United legend Rio Ferdinand has urged Phil Foden to \"dominate\" his compatriots to become one of England's best players. Ferdinand likened Foden's situation to that of Man Utd flop Juan Sebastian Veron, who also struggled to assert himself on the pitch.\n\nManchester City ace Foden, who won the 2023-24 Premier League Player of the Season award, looked like a shadow of his brilliant self in England's 1-0 victory over Serbia in their first game of UEFA EURO 2024. Deployed on the left flank, Foden found himself isolated at times, struggling to get on the ball. He also rarely made inroads into the Serbian box, whereas the likes of Jude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka penetrated the area with ease.\n\nOver the course of the game, Foden failed to dispatch even a single shot, let alone land one on target. He also had just one touch inside the opposition box and created a single chance for his teammates.\n\nOn his FIVE podcast, ex-England international Ferdinand discussed why Foden was struggling for England despite playing world-class soccer for Manchester City. The former center-back claimed that the 24-year-old was was not vocal enough, which allowed the likes of Bellingham to take the spotlight away from him. Ferdinand added that the same happened to Veron, who surrendered control to Roy Keane and eventually left United after making just 51 Premier League appearances.\n\nFerdinand said (via Manchester Evening News):\n\n\"Me, Micah [Richards] and Cesc [Fabregas] done that game [for BBC ] the other day and Micah was saying how he felt sorry for Phil and about how [Gareth] Southgate's not getting the best out of him. And then, to be fair, Cesc just put him away, just said, 'listen, no, no, no, it's down to Foden'. Foden's got to go out there and you're talking about body language, being demanding and authoritative with the way that you want the ball.\n\n\"Jude [Bellingham] has got that in spades and I think if we're going to see the best out of Phil Foden, and I agree with Cesc, he's got to really go out there and try and dominate the pitch and dominate some of his teammates to give him the ball and be the first one to shout.\"\n\nDrawing likenesses with Veron's situation at United, Ferdinand added:\n\n\"But I've seen this before at Man United. We had Roy Keane who demanded the ball in the middle of the pitch. We signed a superstar in Juan Sebastian Veron.\n\n\"He was a playmaker that wanted to get the ball off all of the players and that's how he got his rhythm and play. But Roy Keane dominated because he was more animated, the characteristics that he had came out and was much more dominant.\"\n\nHe concluded by adding:\n\n\"He was there before and dominated that area. And Veron folded really and had to be sold and didn't really become a success at Man United. But he was a fantastically talented player and I hope Phil doesn't fall like that.\"\n\nFoden has played 35 matches for England in all competitions, scoring just four times and providing eight assists. He needs to want it more than the rest and for me today, it showed that Jude (Bellingham) is a little bit above him in this regard.\"\n\nBut Keane did not agree, saying on ITV of Foden's performance: \"I thought he done okay, but this idea that the manager should take him out of the team... Phil Foden is an amazing, fantastic player. He's had a great season. Okay he was quiet last night, but he's entitled to an off night.\n\n\"But don't be writing this kid off. He's got so much talent. {"uri": "8185469000", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:17:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:17:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:17:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com/stories/soccer/what-should-england-do-about-its-jude-bellingham-and-phil-foden-problem", "title": "What should England do about its Jude Bellingham and Phil Foden problem?", "body": "The answer, if you're England head coach Gareth Southgate, is ... a bit of a problem.\n\nManchester City's Phil Foden and Real Madrid's Jude Bellingham were the deserving winners of the respective player of the season awards in the EPL and Spain's top division just a few weeks ago.\n\nAnd yet, as Southgate's group prepares for its second Euro 2024 match, against Denmark in Frankfurt on Thursday (noon ET on FS1), there are growing questions about how they fit together.\n\nIn England's opener, a 1-0 victory over Serbia in Group C, Bellingham more than lived up to the hype, heading home the only goal and generating a tireless, powerful and composed performance.\n\nFoden, however, looked a little lost at times, unable to replicate the swift-footed movements and incisive passes that were his trademark during the domestic season with four-peat EPL title winner City.\n\n\"Jude's obviously an exceptional talent,\" Foden told reporters. \"He carries himself really well. He's a leader now. I think he's turning into a leader. I think our link-up play is good at times and I think it's improving as well, and can keep getting better. So, he's an exciting talent and I enjoy playing with him.\"\n\nSouthgate has some options, and finding the right one could determine whether England is able to live up to its pre-tournament billing as favorite to lift the trophy.\n\n[Euro 2024 team futures]\n\nHe could leave things as they are, with Bellingham in an advanced \"No. 10\" position and Foden on the left, plus Bukayo Saka remaining in the right-sided position from where he was effective against Serbia, and hope that the chemistry gets better as the tournament progresses.\n\nSouthgate could also drop Bellingham into something more closely resembling the deeper midfield spot he most often occupied before his move to Madrid.\n\nHowever, such was the explosive effectiveness of that switch over the past year, that it seems unlikely he would wish to do so, even though it would allow Foden to gravitate more toward the middle.\n\nA final alternative would be to leave Foden out altogether, and use a more natural left-sided player like Chelsea youngster Cole Palmer or Newcastle's Anthony Gordon on that flank.\n\nThat would seem harsh given Foden's level of performance during the club season, and Southgate's insistence that his primary method for choosing his squad was the quality of each player's form in the most recent campaign.\n\n[Want great stories delivered right to your inbox? Create or log in to your FOX Sports account, follow leagues, teams and players to receive a personalized newsletter daily.]\n\nSouthgate did have some positive words to say about Foden's defensive efforts, and the remaining group games will likely have a different tactical feel. Neither Denmark nor Slovenia has shown any inclination to employ a congested back-five like that used by Serbia head coach Dragan Stojkovic.\n\nAlmost as much of a concern as how the 24-year-old links with Bellingham will be the way he seemed unable to get on the same page as England left-back Kieran Trippier, stifling any attempt at fluidity down that channel.\n\n\"I think the first game of a major tournament is always the most difficult,\" Foden added. \"I think it's important to get off to a win and, yeah, we did that. It was difficult at times. Obviously, we had to defend at times and dig deep.\n\n\"But I think that shows a different side to us and if we're going to win something, I think that we have to do that.\"\n\nDenmark presents as England's toughest test of the group stage. Despite managing only a 1-1 tie in its clash with Slovenia, the Danes are a highly-skilled unit and pushed Southgate's squad close when the sides met in the semifinal of Euro 2020, which was delayed until the following year due to COVID.\n\nHead coach Kasper Hjulmand has an attacking issue of his own as his star forward, Rasmus Hojlund of Manchester United, has scored only once in his last nine games for the national team and missed a one-on-one with goalkeeper Jan Oblak against Slovenia. He was replaced by Yussuf Poulsen with seven minutes left.\n\n\"It comes in phases as a striker,\" Hjulmand told a press conference. \"Rasmus always makes a big difference, so it's not a concern, and I am sure the goals will come.\"", "source": {"uri": "foxsports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jude_Bellingham", {"uri": "8185949575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:05:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:05:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:04:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/englands-team-vs-denmark-leaked-gareth-southgate/", "title": "England's team to face Denmark has 'leaked' with Gareth Southgate making some big calls", "body": "Highlights England are looking to advance in Euro 2024 as they take on Denmark after beating Serbia 1-0. The team to play next had been leaked in the press already with Gareth Southgate showing faith in his players. Alan Shearer wanted Anthony Gordon to start but he looks set to be disappointed.\n\nHaving won their first game against Serbia by a single goal, all eyes now turn to Denmark as England aim to advance out of their Euro 2024 group and go deep into the tournament.\n\nBefore the game even begins, Gareth Southgate will have a big decision to make. Indeed, he must name the XI he feels is best placed to get him across the line.\n\nThe Three Lions weren't exactly brilliant against Serbia but they did get all three points. Now, less than 24 hours before the game, it appears as though the national team manager has made peace with that performance. At least that's the impression given upon viewing the team which has been leaked in the press.\n\nEngland XI vs Denmark Southgate remains unchanged\n\nAccording to journalist Sami Mokbel, Southgate will stick with an unchanged team against the Danes. While it's no surprise that the spine of the team will stay the same, there has been some doubt over a few different positions.\n\nNamely, Phil Foden and Trent Alexander-Arnold struggled to impress. As such, the likes of Anthony Gordon and Conor Gallagher have both been touted as possible candidates to come into the team.\n\nThe Liverpool right-back - playing in central midfield - was substituted in place of Gallagher in the second half and the Chelsea man worked hard to help England hand on to all three points. Gordon did not get onto the pitch vs Serbia but his speed is viewed as making him a better fit to play alongside Harry Kane and Bukayo Saka in the front line.\n\nRelated 3 England Players Gareth Southgate Should Have Taken to Euro 2024\n\nThe Three Lions are missing some key players who could have made them even better\n\nThe good news is that Kieran Trippier seems fit to play. Mokbel noted that he appeared to be in some discomfort during the closing stages of the first game but is now in line to win his 50th cap. With Luke Shaw still out injured, the Newcastle defender's fitness is vital for the Three Lions - perhaps he's been boosted by pickle juice.\n\nShaw hasn't played since February due to a hamstring injury and didn't train with his team-mates on Wednesday. It was hoped that the Manchester United left-back would be fit enough to play some part in the game vs Denmark but it remains unclear if he'll even be back in time for any of the group stages.\n\nEngland 1-0 Serbia\n\nStat\n\nEngland\n\nSerbia\n\nPossession\n\n53.2%\n\n46.8%\n\nShots\n\n5\n\n6\n\nShots on Target\n\n3\n\n1\n\nTotal touches in the box\n\n12\n\n11\n\nCorner\n\n1\n\n2\n\nFouls\n\n8\n\n19\n\nMarc Guehi impressed in the backline alongside John Stones and so has done more than enough to retain his spot in the side, while the likes of Jude Bellingham, Declan Rice and Saka all stood out against Serbia. Kane will hope to have more of an influence on proceedings this time out, as he managed just two touches of the ball during the first half of England's opening fixture.\n\nAlan Shearer Wants Gordon to Start Foden pushed into midfield with Rice and Bellingham\n\nIf the team does stay the same, the news might not go down too well with Alan Shearer. The former England striker had a few ideas on how to get the best out of Foden.\n\nIndeed, he wanted just one change made to the team with Gordon coming into the XI for Alexander-Arnold. This would mean Bellingham would drop down beside Rice, with Foden moving into an attacking midfielder role and the Newcastle winger heading to the left flank.\n\nHe explained: \"Trippier is a really, really good full-back. But having a right-footed player at left-back, when he's receiving the ball, he's receiving the ball facing the goalkeeper rather than facing out to the left-hand side. So I don't think that actually helped Foden in that position either.\"\n\nIt remains to be seen how patient Southgate will be with Foden and Alexander-Arnold. Another underwhelming display could prompt the English manager into changes soon enough and they both seem to be at risk.\n\nRelated Bukayo Saka vs Phil Foden's Total England Career Stats Comparison {"uri": "2024-06-395786239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:00:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:00:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:34:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/england-news-fans-name-2-players-get-rid-of-euro-2024", "title": "England fans name 2 players to get rid of at Euro 2024", "body": "England fans have taken to social media to express their frustration over Gareth Southgate's decision for the squad vs. Denmark at Euro 2024\n\nEngland fans have taken to social media to express their frustration over Gareth Southgate's decision to start both Trent Alexander-Arnold and Phil Foden against Denmark in their upcoming Euro 2024 fixture, reported by GOAL. Despite a less-than-impressive performance against Serbia, Southgate seems intent on maintaining an unchanged starting eleven, which has left supporters baffled and outraged.\n\nAccording to multiple reports, Southgate is set to field the same starting XI that played against Serbia. This decision means Alexander-Arnold and Foden will keep their places, despite heavy criticism for their recent performances. Southgate's preference for continuity after just one game suggests he believes in giving his players another chance to prove themselves.\n\nFan reactions\n\nPhil Foden's display on the left wing against Serbia drew significant ire from fans, many of whom feel he should be dropped from the starting lineup. Social media was ablaze with criticism directed at the Manchester City star.\n\n@FrankyRN51 didn't mince words, posting: \"Foden needs [to be] dropped.\"\n\nAnother user, @thefmetzger, was even more blunt: \"Foden should be on the beach in Ibiza.\"\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold, who was deployed in an unfamiliar midfield role, received a mixed reaction. Some fans sympathized with his struggle in a new position, while others felt he didn't deserve to start.\n\n@LFC_Laith showed support for Alexander-Arnold but criticized Foden: \"Good on Trent he deserves it but Foden stinks.\"\n\nConversely, @madm0007 was shocked by the decision to include Alexander-Arnold: \"Shock!! So obvious. TAA in, really?\"\n\n@allstars_aag defended Alexander-Arnold: \"Why's Trent included in this.. Starboy Phil dropped an absolute stinker.\"\n\nDespite concerns about Kieran Trippier's fitness after he was seen struggling with cramps towards the end of the Serbia match, he is reportedly fit to start against Denmark. His availability is a boost for Southgate, who relies on Trippier's experience and versatility.\n\nUnfortunately for England, Luke Shaw will not be available for the Denmark match as he continues to recover from a hamstring injury. This ongoing absence leaves a gap in the defensive lineup, putting additional pressure on Southgate to get his team selection right.\n\nThe stakes against Denmark at Euro 2024\n\nEngland's narrow victory over Serbia has set the stage for a crucial clash with Denmark. A win on Friday would guarantee England a place in the knockout stages of Euro 2024. The pressure is on for key players like Harry Kane, Alexander-Arnold, and Foden to step up and deliver strong performances to silence their critics and secure England's progression in the tournament.\n\nHarry Kane, England's captain and talisman, will be looking to lead by example and find the back of the net. a dilemma even the great Sir Bobby Robson was unable to solve.\n\nFast forward 30 years and the same conundrum associated with Barnes, and to a certain degree Paul Scholes, is now firmly at the feet of Manchester City's Phil Foden.\n\nFoden was elected the Premier League Player of the Season following his best campaign to date which saw him register 27 goals across all competitions.\n\nHowever, the great hopes placed upon him ahead of England's Euro 2024 bid were quickly dispelled during Sunday's 1-0 win over Serbia.\n\nFoden started well in Gelsenkirchen but gradually faded as the game wore on - a stark contrast to his dazzling displays for City.\n\nThe 24-year-old is yet to impress in an England shirt in the way he so often does under Pep Guardiola.\n\nFour goals in 34 caps is not the only measuring stick for a player of his ability but performances for the Three Lions have fallen short of the bar he has set himself at club level.\n\nFormer Liverpool ace Barnes knows first hand what Foden is experiencing and revealed a discussion he had with ex-England boss Robson who questioned why he was unable to replicate his club form.\n\n\"It's like having an out-of-body experience,\" Barnes told talKSPORT. \"I went through something very similar.\n\n\"Sir Bobby Robson used to say to me, 'We want you to play for England the way you play for Liverpool'.\n\n\"You know what I said to him? 'If England played the way Liverpool do, then I would'.\n\n\"It's the same for Foden. Whether you put Foden on the left, the middle or the right, unless England are going to play like Man City, nothing will change.\n\n\"The left-back for Man City is Josko Gvardiol. He's not a left-footer. The way Man City play suits him.\n\n\"It doesn't matter about using him, Anthony Gordon, Cole Palmer... unless England play the way their clubs play, it doesn't matter. You'll never get the best out of them.\"\n\nBarnes continued: \"If Jude Bellingham is going to be the No.10, the playmaker on the ball all the time, all Foden will be is a bit-part player. Work hard, defend, give the ball to Bellingham.\n\n\"Therefore, what is he doing there? It doesn't matter what position he plays. The football, the tactics, the template of how they play, the way they move the ball... unless it's going to be like Man City, you'll never see the best of Foden.\"\n\nAn air of panic would be too {"uri": "8186625243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "08:29:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T08:29:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T08:28:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/gareth-southgate-options-best-jude-082000212.html", "title": "Gareth Southgate's options to get best out of Jude Bellingham and Phil Foden", "body": "England is in the midst of a rush to the centre ground, with so many of Gareth Southgate's squad in a battle to occupy No 10. Traditionalists still believe it would be wiser to drag Phil Foden towards the left, while Trent Alexander-Arnold is thought by most fans and pundits to be more comfortable on the right. The only consensus according to all opinion polls is Jude Bellingham holds the key.\n\nSo how can England coach Southgate unite the different factions for the greater good of the nation? Telegraph Sport looks at his tactical options ahead of the Euro 2014 group game against Denmark on Thursday night.\n\nThe sample size upon which a few thousand words of forensic analysis have been dedicated to England's new-look midfield is so minuscule, it serves to underline what a thankless job being a national coach is. Southgate and his assistant Steve Holland have worked out a formula to enable Foden and Bellingham to circulate in the central areas where they inflict most damage on opponents - as shown by England's first goal of the tournament.\n\nFor 45 minutes against Serbia it worked. Foden, Bellingham and Trent Alexander-Arnold interconnected, closing gaps across the centre of the pitch, and retaining possession with precise, well-paced passes, dragging the Serbian defence into uncomfortable areas. With Declan Rice in supreme form as the deepest midfielder, the balance looked good. The dominance did not last into the second half, but the theory this is because of Foden and Bellingham's positioning is half-baked.\n\nThe main worry in the latter stages against the Serbs was England's fatigue. Ditching the master plan after one game would smack of weakness and suggest Southgate is too preoccupied with populist propaganda. The system needs to evolve - most notably by ordering Harry Kane to make more runs beyond the shoulders of defenders, as Bukayo Saka does - but England's so-called midfield 'problem' has been greatly exaggerated. It is their strongest area.\n\nIf Harry Kane is going to persist in dropping to the No 10 position because he is frustrated when not getting a touch of the ball, clearly there is a tactical problem against deep defences. The congestion 40 yards from goal as Foden, Bellingham, Alexander-Arnold and Kane exchange passes will leave Saka as the only one making forward runs to occupy defenders and benefit from Alexander-Arnold's ability to find a killer pass. That reduces the Liverpool's man's effectiveness. In that situation, it makes more sense to select an out-and-out left winger such as Anthony Gordon to replicate Saka's role on the right.\n\nAsking Foden to play more as a left midfielder will not make much difference as he always drifts inside anyway rather than sprinting beyond full-backs. That means if Southgate has doubts about the system already - which is doubtful - and wants a left midfielder getting chalk on his boots, he will probably have to sacrifice Foden. But Southgate will be thinking longer-term. To win the tournament, England must beat one of the more technically proficient teams like Spain, Portugal and Germany, where previous wounding experiences proved the ability to retain possession is pivotal to controlling the game.\n\nIn those games, England outnumbering teams in the middle can be a supreme advantage - especially with players so comfortable on the ball - and Gordon's pace will be a more potent weapon between 70-90 minutes when the games open up against tiring defences.\n\nWhen England were at their best on Sunday, Rice was effectively this already as the Serbs were pinned back and Alexander-Arnold was too advanced to be described as a second No 6. Nevertheless, there are many who will argue that if Southgate likes this set-up so much it is more logical to select an out-and-out midfielder rather than someone learning on the job, especially at international level.\n\nIf Rice is the only holding midfielder, Bellingham and Foden can continue to play as interchanging No 10s and a space is freed for another attacker, with either Anthony Gordon on the left, or one of the Chelsea offensive midfield duo of Cole Palmer or Conor Gallagher. Picking Gordon ahead of Alexander-Arnold is illogical because the Newcastle man would be beneficiary of the playmaker's service. If one of Chelsea players replaces Alexander-Arnold, Kane will still need to play further up the pitch to stop getting in the way of the creative midfielders.\n\nAlso, any clamour for Palmer and Gallagher to be picked over Alexander-Arnold is contradictory since the main concerns about the Liverpool man focus on his defensive capacities. Leaving sole responsibility to Rice to protect the back four will make England more vulnerable against the strongest nations. So with this option, the midfield looks more imbalanced.\n\nAs Jamie Carragher pointed out in his post-Serbia Telegraph column, the main tactical concern for England on Sunday night was not the balance of the midfield, but how it impacted on Harry Kane. If Kane plays as a traditional No 9 it gives the creative players multiple passing options and the balance is better. Foden can indulge on his mazy dribbles and through balls, Bellingham can find the spaces between centre-backs as they are occupied by an out-and-out striker, and Alexander-Arnold has a six yard box target for his pinpoint deliveries.\n\nWhen Kane keeps dropping deep, the midfielders look up and see nothing. That is the opposite of what Foden is confronted with when taking possession for City, or Alexander-Arnold when adopting the hybrid role for Liverpool and seeing Mohamed Salah, Luis Diaz and Darwin Nunez dashing beyond defenders. If Kane is disciplined in his task as a target man, Foden and Bellingham can operate 'between the lines'. The tactical dilemma then is whether Kane is being compromised too much to accommodate all the midfielders.\n\nIt is a work in progress and too early for definitive conclusions. {"uri": "8186633586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "08:35:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T08:35:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T08:34:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2024/06/20/gareth-southgate-england-jude-bellingham-phil-foden-denmark/", "title": "Gareth Southgate's options to get best out of Jude Bellingham and Phil Foden", "body": "England's midfield 'problem' has been greatly exaggerated - but Harry Kane is key to making it work\n\nEngland is in the midst of a rush to the centre ground, with so many of Gareth Southgate's squad in a battle to occupy No 10. Traditionalists still believe it would be wiser to drag Phil Foden towards the left, while Trent Alexander-Arnold is thought by most fans and pundits to be more comfortable on the right. The only consensus according to all opinion polls is Jude Bellingham holds the key.\n\nSo how can England coach Southgate unite the different factions for the greater good of the nation? Telegraph Sport looks at his tactical options ahead of the Euro 2014 group game against Denmark on Thursday night.\n\nOPTION ONE: Change nothing\n\nThe sample size upon which a few thousand words of forensic analysis have been dedicated to England's new-look midfield is so minuscule, it serves to underline what a thankless job being a national coach is. Southgate and his assistant Steve Holland have worked out a formula to enable Foden and Bellingham to circulate in the central areas where they inflict most damage on opponents - as shown by England's first goal of the tournament.\n\nFor 45 minutes against Serbia it worked. Foden, Bellingham and Trent Alexander-Arnold interconnected, closing gaps across the centre of the pitch, and retaining possession with precise, well-paced passes, dragging the Serbian defence into uncomfortable areas. With Declan Rice in supreme form as the deepest midfielder, the balance looked good. The dominance did not last into the second half, but the theory this is because of Foden and Bellingham's positioning is half-baked.\n\nThe main worry in the latter stages against the Serbs was England's fatigue. Ditching the master plan after one game would smack of weakness and suggest Southgate is too preoccupied with populist propaganda. The system needs to evolve - most notably by ordering Harry Kane to make more runs beyond the shoulders of defenders, as Bukayo Saka does - but England's so-called midfield 'problem' has been greatly exaggerated. It is their strongest area.\n\nOPTION TWO: Drop Foden\n\nIf Harry Kane is going to persist in dropping to the No 10 position because he is frustrated when not getting a touch of the ball, clearly there is a tactical problem against deep defences. The congestion 40 yards from goal as Foden, Bellingham, Alexander-Arnold and Kane exchange passes will leave Saka as the only one making forward runs to occupy defenders and benefit from Alexander-Arnold's ability to find a killer pass. That reduces the Liverpool's man's effectiveness. In that situation, it makes more sense to select an out-and-out left winger such as Anthony Gordon to replicate Saka's role on the right.\n\nAsking Foden to play more as a left midfielder will not make much difference as he always drifts inside anyway rather than sprinting beyond full-backs. That means if Southgate has doubts about the system already - which is doubtful - and wants a left midfielder getting chalk on his boots, he will probably have to sacrifice Foden. But Southgate will be thinking longer-term. To win the tournament, England must beat one of the more technically proficient teams like Spain, Portugal and Germany, where previous wounding experiences proved the ability to retain possession is pivotal to controlling the game.\n\nIn those games, England outnumbering teams in the middle can be a supreme advantage - especially with players so comfortable on the ball - and Gordon's pace will be a more potent weapon between 70-90 minutes when the games open up against tiring defences.\n\nOPTION THREE: Play Rice as the only holding midfielder\n\nWhen England were at their best on Sunday, Rice was effectively this already as the Serbs were pinned back and Alexander-Arnold was too advanced to be described as a second No 6. Nevertheless, there are many who will argue that if Southgate likes this set-up so much it is more logical to select an out-and-out midfielder rather than someone learning on the job, especially at international level.\n\nIf Rice is the only holding midfielder, Bellingham and Foden can continue to play as interchanging No 10s and a space is freed for another attacker, with either Anthony Gordon on the left, or one of the Chelsea offensive midfield duo of Cole Palmer or Conor Gallagher. Picking Gordon ahead of Alexander-Arnold is illogical because the Newcastle man would be beneficiary of the playmaker's service. If one of Chelsea players replaces Alexander-Arnold, Kane will still need to play further up the pitch to stop getting in the way of the creative midfielders.\n\nAlso, any clamour for Palmer and Gallagher to be picked over Alexander-Arnold is contradictory since the main concerns about the Liverpool man focus on his defensive capacities. Leaving sole responsibility to Rice to protect the back four will make England more vulnerable against the strongest nations. So with this option, the midfield looks more imbalanced.\n\nOPTION FOUR: Play Kane as out-and-out No 9\n\nAs Jamie Carragher pointed out in his post-Serbia Telegraph column, the main tactical concern for England on Sunday night was not the balance of the midfield, but how it impacted on Harry Kane. If Kane plays as a traditional No 9 it gives the creative players multiple passing options and the balance is better. Foden can indulge on his mazy dribbles and through balls, Bellingham can find the spaces between centre-backs as they are occupied by an out-and-out striker, and Alexander-Arnold has a six yard box target for his pinpoint deliveries.\n\nWhen Kane keeps dropping deep, the midfielders look up and see nothing. That is the opposite of what Foden is confronted with when taking possession for City, or Alexander-Arnold when adopting the hybrid role for Liverpool and seeing Mohamed Salah, Luis Diaz and Darwin Nunez dashing beyond defenders. If Kane is disciplined in his task as a target man, Foden and Bellingham can operate 'between the lines'. The tactical dilemma then is whether Kane is being compromised too much to accommodate all the midfielders.\n\nIt is a work in progress and too early for definitive conclusions. With England virtually guaranteed qualification into the knockout phase, the Denmark and Slovenia fixtures are a chance to cast further judgments and iron out the flaws.", "source": {"uri": Sometimes you can't get all your best players in the starting eleven.\n\nIt probably would be Foden if someone has to be sacrificed. When you try to accommodate all your best players and it doesn't work out, then a decision has to be made. In management at the international level, you can't please everyone.
