{"uri": "8187000604", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:19:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:19:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:18:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.news18.com/football/euro-2024-england-boss-gareth-southgate-feels-phil-foden-did-an-incredible-job-in-england-opener-against-serbia-8938812.html", "title": "Euro 2024: England Boss Gareth Southgate Feels Phil Foden 'Did An Incredible Job' In England Opener Against Serbia - News18", "body": "The English manager opined the Manchester City star made a great impact with his off-the-ball movements despite not finding his place in the scoresheet.\n\nEngland midfielder Phil Foden drew criticism after his pale show in the EURO opener against Serbia on June 17. The Three Lions secured a narrow win in the Group C game, with Real Madrid star Jude Bellingham scoring the only goal with a stunning header early in the first half.\n\nFoden, who operated from the left flank, failed to showcase his A-game in Gelsenkirchen. England boss Gareth Southgate, however, seems not quite worried about Foden's form. The manager feels the Manchester City star made a great impact with his off-the-ball movements despite not finding his place in the scoresheet.\n\nWith England gearing up for their next EURO assignment against Denmark, Southgate will likely go with the same playing eleven that featured in the previous match. After the opening game, there were widespread speculations about if Foden would be able to keep his place in the team. Southgate has now rubbished those claims, praising the 24-year-old midfielder for his performance against Serbia.\n\n\"I thought Phil did an incredible job for the team on Sunday. You know, sometimes the bits with the ball are obvious and they catch the eye, but the amount of ground he covered, the angles of pressing, the filling in for people who were further forward. I thought without Phil's contribution without the ball - and I know that's not the sexy bit and everybody wants to see him on the ball - I don't think we win the game,\" Southgate explained in a press conference, as quoted by Sky Sports.\n\nThe England manager further shed light on Foden's role in the midfield, saying, \"Towards the end of the game he retained the ball for us in really crucial moments. He had a half chance in the first couple of minutes where a slightly better touch and a shot away on goal we could be talking about something very different. He linked the game well in that opening period with the others. And we were happy with what Phil did,\" the Mirror quoted.\n\nFoden claimed his fourth consecutive title with Manchester City this season before shifting his focus to the EURO. During the 2023-24 campaign, the English midfielder scored 27 goals and provided 12 assists in 53 appearances for his club across all competitions. {"uri": "8185491547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:35:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:35:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:33:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/rio-ferdinand-compares-phil-foden-134300225.html", "title": "Rio Ferdinand compares Phil Foden to Manchester United flop", "body": "Former Manchester United and England centre-back Rio Ferdinand has compared Phil Foden to Juan Sebastian Veron.\n\nFoden struggled to impact England's Euro 2024 opener, which ended in a 1-0 win over Serbia. It was a nervy win for Gareth Southgate's side as they never appeared to dominate the game.\n\nDespite the criticism aimed towards Foden in the past week, the Man City midfielder played a key role in Pep Guardiola's side winning the title. He looks a lot more comfortable when playing in City's system which is the case for the vast majority of their players.\n\nFerdinand believes Foden needs to \"dominate\" his teammates more and demand the ball if he's to shine at the Euros this summer.\n\nSpeaking on his FIVE podcast, Ferdinand said: \"Me, Micah [Richards] and Cesc [Fabregas] done that game [for BBC] the other day and Micah was saying how he felt sorry for Phil and about how [Gareth] Southgate's not getting the best out of him.\n\n\"And then, to be fair, Cesc just put him away, just said, 'listen, no, no, no, it's down to Foden'. Foden's got to go out there and you're talking about body language, being demanding and authoritative with the way that you want the ball.\n\n\"Jude [Bellingham] has got that in spades and I think if we're going to see the best out of Phil Foden, and I agree with Cesc, he's got to really go out there and try and dominate the pitch and dominate some of his teammates to give him the ball and be the first one to shout.\"\n\nFerdinand added: \"But I've seen this before at Man United. We had Roy Keane who demanded the ball in the middle of the pitch. We signed a superstar in Juan Sebastian Veron. Ridiculous player, the streets will never forget this guy, that bandage under the knee.\n\n\"He was a playmaker that wanted to get the ball off all of the players and that's how he got his rhythm and play. But Roy Keane dominated because he was more animated, the characteristics that he had came out and was much more dominant.\n\n\"He was there before and dominated that area. And Veron folded really and had to be sold and didn't really become a success at Man United. {"uri": "2024-06-395985209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:42:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:42:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:14:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://sportslens.com/news/phil-foden-kyle-walker-england-manchester-city/", "title": "England: Walker Backs Under-Fire Foden To Rise To The Occasion", "body": "England and Manchester City right-back Kyle Walker has lauded teammate Phil Foden, asking his critics not to judge him after just one performance. Walker also backed Foden to \"rise to the occasion\", suggesting he has the quality to become one of England's star performers in the 2024 European Championship (EURO 2024).\n\nEngland & Manchester City Ace Phil Foden Has Received Criticism For Subdued Display In EURO 2024 Opener\n\nManchester City attacker Foden was not at his best in England's 1-0 victory over Serbia last Sunday (June 16). He did not get as involved in the game as many had hoped, spending the entire night on the fringes. The 2023-24 Premier League Player of the Season registered just one touch inside the Serbian box, created one solitary chance, and failed to dispatch any shot.\n\nFormer England internationals and pundits, Micah Richards and Rio Ferdinand have discussed in length about Foden's disappointing EURO 2024 debut. While Richards said the 24-year-old lacked support down the left flank, Ferdinand urged him to be more vocal and dominant to get his share of the ball.\n\nWalker, meanwhile, has asked everyone to take a beat and deliver their verdict about Foden at the end of the tournament.\n\nKyle Walker Lends Support To Teammate With Great Character\n\nSpeaking to the press ahead of England's Matchday 2 clash against Denmark, Walker said:\n\n\"I don't think one game defines a player. It's a season or a tournament that defines a player. Especially with Phil coming off the back of the season he had, I don't think one 90 minutes should be scrutinized as much as I'm being told it is.\n\n\"Phil is a great character, he's had, I wouldn't say a difficult path to get here, as he's won a lot of trophies at Manchester City, but he's had to be patient.\"\n\nHe concluded by adding:\n\n\"This is just another little thing he has to overcome when there is so much pressure on him now after such a great season, that big players have to rise up on big occasions.\"\n\nFoden, who won the U17 FIFA World Cup with England in 2018, has played 35 {"uri": "8184809571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:02:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:02:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:01:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/ferdinand-foden-england-euro2024-veron-33060002", "title": "Rio Ferdinand compares Phil Foden to \u00a328m Man Utd flop after England no-show", "body": "Phil Foden struggled to make an impact for England on the left wing\n\nPhil Foden failed to make much of an impact in England's Euro 2024 opener and Rio Ferdinand has compared his struggles to that of Juan Sebastian Veron at Manchester United.\n\nWith Jude Bellingham playing in Foden's preferred No.10 role, the Manchester City star was given a chance out wide on the left. However, he was unable to have the same influence on the game as he does for City, with Bellingham ultimately scoring the winner as England beat Serbia 1-0.\n\nAnd former Spain star Cesc Fabregas, who won the Euros twice in 2008 and 2012, suggested after the game that Foden needs \"impose himself\" on the game more like Bellingham did. Ferdinand agrees with Fabregas' assessment, claiming Foden is in a similar situation to Veron who was a \"ridiculous player\" but struggled at United because Roy Keane was \"much more dominant\".\n\nSpeaking on his FIVE podcast,\" Ferdinand said: \"Me, Micah [Richards] and Cesc done that game [for BBC ] the other day and Micah was saying how he felt sorry for Phil that and about how Southgate's not getting the best out of him.\n\n\"And then to be fair Cesc just put him away, just said, 'listen, no, no, no, it's down to Foden'. Foden's got to go out there and you're talking about body language, being demanding and authoritative with the way that you want the ball.\n\n\"Jude has got that in spades and I think if we're going to see the best out of Phil Foden, and I agree with Cesc, he's got to really go out there and try and dominate the pitch and dominate some of his teammates to give him the ball and be the first one to shout.\n\n\"But I've seen this before at Man United. We had Roy Keane who demanded the ball in the middle of the pitch. We signed a superstar in Juan Sebastian Veron. Ridiculous player, the streets will never forget this guy, that bandage under the knee...\n\n\"He was a playmaker that wanted to get the ball off all of the players and that's how he got his rhythm and play. {"uri": "8182978114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "05:41:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T05:41:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T05:40:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/24392220.euro-2024-assessing-englands-performance-serbia/", "title": "EURO VIEW: Celebrating the best and the worst of an 'OK' England performance", "body": "Gareth Southgate will be delighted that England got over the line against Serbia in their Euros opener but after a dominant first half, their showing after the interval raised more questions than provided answers.\n\nEngland were impressive in the opening 35 minutes. Jude Bellingham dominated the match, strutting his stuff. It was a relief to see him given the freedom to roam from the number 10 position, often dropping back into deeper areas to collect the ball and create.\n\nThere were a few important tackles and blocks from the Real Madrid man, who looks far more effective with the picture ahead of him. His strength and power make him a perfect box-to-box, do-it-all midfielder, not someone who should be confined to the top-end of the pitch.\n\nThe way Bellingham dominated the centre of the pitch was reminiscent of Steven Gerrard. The perfect timing of his late run into the box was Frank Lampard-esque. The sheer desire to meet Bukayo Saka's cross outweighed the defender and produced the decisive moment.\n\nThe Arsenal winger was the main competition for Bellingham's player-of-the-match award on first-half evidence. With his team-mate roaming and Phil Foden drifting, Saka gave them the width needed and constantly beat his full-back.\n\nI don't know what happened in the second half but England were a different team. Southgate alluded to fitness issues perhaps tempting them to defend deeper. Possibly?\n\nThe way they surrendered the ascendency was worrying, as was the England boss' lack of reaction from the bench. I am not a Southgate basher by any means but criticism of his in-game management can't be defended, at times.\n\nIt was clear on the hour-mark that England had run out of steam, needed more legs in the middle and a better outlet out wide to stretch Serbia.\n\nConnor Gallagher came 10 minutes too late, as did Jarrod Bowen. Anthony Gordon should've been introduced too given how ineffective Foden became and how lop-sided their attack was.\n\nThe biggest concern for me in the group stages is England's left side. How do they get a better balance? Well, hopefully, Luke Shaw will be fit soon and that will certainly help, but it's worrying to rely on a half-cooked defender who hasn't played since February.\n\nFor the good of the team, Southgate either needs to compromise or drop one of his star attackers. On the evidence of the first half, I see no reason why Declan Rice, who was excellent, Bellingham and Foden can't play together. Particularly, against weaker opposition.\n\nIf Southgate is insistent that isn't for him then someone has to be sacrificed for the balance of the team. England have always looked at their best with runners beyond Harry Kane, think Raheem Sterling and Marcus Rashford at their best.\n\nThe captain was isolated and ineffectual, particularly second half, through little fault of his own. England would be a far better team, in my opinion, with Saka and Gordon in the team, on either flank.\n\nFoden has not produced the moments of magic we've seen regularly for Manchester City. Saka and Bellingham's contributions in an England shirt far outweigh his, unfortunately.\n\nIt would be a crying shame if someone as talented as Foden can't get in the England team. But it would be even worse to jeopardise the effectiveness of the team just to shoe-horn him in.\n\nEngland's defence stood up to the challenge, which was a big positive. Bellingham shrugged off any worries of burn-out or fatigue. But the same nagging doubts weren't eased on matchday one.\n\nPhil Foden had an off night for England - but was it the end of the world? (Image: PA)\n\nEngland View - Marc Iles:\n\nNothing can be 'okay' anymore, as England found out on Sunday night.\n\nIn the lawless land of social media, you are either the greatest thing since sliced bread or the worst manager, player or team in the world, there is no middle ground.\n\nYou don't have to search very far to know what I mean. Phil Foden put out a tweet not long after the final whistle of a 1-0 win against Serbia, met largely by a barrage of abuse from nameless morons who should have been in bed.\n\nHe didn't play particularly well and there is definitely a wider debate to be had about his starting position in his England team, and whether he can have the same impact out wide without the guiding hand of a Bernardo Silva or a Kevin De Bruyne around him.\n\nBut judging by some of the comments you'd think his inclusion in the team was somehow controversial, and that he wasn't a generational talent comparable with anyone in this tournament.\n\nHas social media reduced concentration and intellect levels to the point where we can't consider one performance on its merits, and must polarise every single opinion lest we miss out on a few likes?\n\nFoden's performance was a five out of 10, I'd argue the same could be said about Kieran Trippier who played within himself on the left. That literally nothing was going down that side of the pitch for England reinforces those lopsided arguments that have been thrown at England, especially without Luke Shaw.\n\nI can understand disappointment that the team became unnecessarily submissive in the second half and there were some poor choices in possession all over the pitch which meant they could not build attacks in the same way they did over the first half an hour.\n\nIt might just mean, however, that England are a good team finding their form, not a great one taking backward steps. And that's OK, it might still be enough to win them the tournament.\n\nJude Bellingham celebrates at the end of the game, in front of those omnipotent Lidl ads (Image: PA)\n\nTV View - Marc Iles:\n\nNearly 15 million people tuned into England v Serbia at its peak - which is four million more than any other UK programme during 2024.\n\nAmazing numbers in this digital world and good ammunition for whoever sells the adverts for these major tournaments.\n\nI don't claim to have a firm grip on global branding but there are some weird company names claiming centre stage in Germany.\n\nI've already expressed my dislike for ITV's coverage giving blanket sponsorship to 'Visit Qatar' though I appreciate it is probably a UEFA tie-in. I am becoming increasingly frustrated at the BBC lobbing in trailers for iPlayer, though, regardless of how well Mark Pougatch builds-up the new season of the Great British Sewing Bee.\n\nThe corporate sponsors have provided some head-scratching moments. The perimeter of the pitch often flashes up someone boasting to be the \"No1 Nev Maker\" - a title that can surely only be bestowed on Gary Neville's grandad.\n\nDavid Beckham pops up in random adverts for Alipay, giving little clue what they actually do, and something called Hisense proudly and ambiguously claims to be ranked \"Number Two Globally\". Well done them.\n\nLidl's name is everywhere, as is a company called Atos, which according to Google specialises in hi-tech transactional services, unified communications, cloud, big data and cybersecurity services. Nope, me neither.\n\nThrow in the fact you can't turn on a laptop up to three hours before an England game without Paddy Power finding some way to offer you a novel way to fritter your money away, and it all leaves you feeling a bit icky.\n\nNot quite as bad, however, as the advert for Hellman's mayonnaise, clearly filmed well in advance of the Euros, which has among its stars Jack Grealish and Marcus Rashford. I've watched a lot of him at Manchester City and I truly believe that he was restricted in his role against Serbia.\n\n\"He wasn't doing what he does for City, starting on the left and popping up in the centre, rotating his position. It seemed like he was made to stay wide on the left-hand side.\n\n\"When you see him at his best, he picks up the ball and can beat as many players as he wants. He plays with freedom at City, but he can't seem to find that with England.\"\n\nAllardyce went on to explain that he would change the setup of England's midfield if he was still in charge of the Three Lions.\n\nHinting that he would take Trent Alexander-Arnold out of the midfield three and play Foden and Bellingham alongside Declan Rice instead.\n\nHe added: \"He's better off in a central role than on the left. He can play on the left but what he's done from midfield for City this season has been outstanding, so that's where I'd like to see him.\n\n\"I'd have Declan Rice as the only sitting midfielder because that's my favourite system.\n\n\"Foden and Bellingham could share the load, when one goes forward the other sits back. However, Denmark will offer a more skill-based challenge than the physical Serbs so Gareth Southgate needs to make a tactical change.\n\nOn Sunday, everything went down the right hand side and Serbia nullified that in the second half knowing that we offered nothing on the left, so that needs to be rectified.\n\nIt pains me to say it, but if we do make a change, maybe Anthony Gordon should play in front of Kieran Trippier with Trent Alexander-Arnold dropping to the bench. That would mean a midfield four of Bukayo Saka, Declan Rice, Jude Bellingham and Gordon, with Phil Foden being allowed more of the freedom he enjoys with Manchester City.\n\nHopefully Harry Kane will be able to make more of an impact on this match but if he doesn't, we have Eberechi Eze on the bench and he could prove to be the surprise package of the tournament if he's given the chance.\n\nThe Danes will give us a good game but I'd go for a 2-1 win for us.\n\nI think the biggest issue is the balance of the team, particularly on the left hand side.\n\nAs a right-footed left back, Kieran Trippier doesn't offer width and Phil Foden isn't a natural left winger, so the vast majority of our attacks against Serbia were coming down the right hand side.\n\nI think Anthony Gordon should start on the left wing.\n\nThat could be in place of Trent Alexander-Arnold, with Jude Bellingham pushing slightly deeper and allowing Foden to play in the number ten position.\n\nAlternatively, he could replace Foden, which would certainly raise some eyebrows.\n\nThe big question concerns Luke Shaw's fitness, as he's another player who would give us some width. If he starts the game and lasts for sixty minutes to regain some match fitness, I think that would be a good move, but getting him back fit is crucial.\n\nIt'll be an interesting team selection on Thursday.\n\nI'd agree with Derek in the main.\n\nWe need to learn from these group games whilst also ensuring we progress, and you could say that if we repeated the first half on Sunday and won 2-0 or 3-0, everyone would be really up for this.\n\nHowever, the second half against Serbia killed off a bit of that potential optimism, but it was a clean sheet and a win so we take it and move on.\n\nAlthough Harry Kane was unlucky not to score from a header after a wonder save from the Serbia goalkeeper, he was rarely involved.\n\nWe can and should get more from such a prolific frontman, and if it isn't working out in the group games- either due to his own efforts or because of how we're feeding him- maybe we should provide some game time for others.\n\nThese games need to be used to {"uri": "8183003614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "06:03:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T06:03:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T06:02:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/24391691.euro-2024-column-englands-big-questions-cautious-optimism/", "title": "Euro 2024: England questions, over-the-top conclusions and revealing numbers", "body": "Gareth Southgate will be delighted that England got over the line against Serbia in their Euros opener but after a dominant first half, their showing after the interval raised more questions than provided answers.\n\nEngland were impressive in the opening 35 minutes. Jude Bellingham dominated the match, strutting his stuff. It was a relief to see him given the freedom to roam from the number 10 position, often dropping back into deeper areas to collect the ball and create.\n\nThere were a few important tackles and blocks from the Real Madrid man, who looks far more effective with the picture ahead of him. His strength and power make him a perfect box-to-box, do-it-all midfielder, not someone who should be confined to the top-end of the pitch.\n\nThe way Bellingham dominated the centre of the pitch was reminiscent of Steven Gerrard. The perfect timing of his late run into the box was Frank Lampard-esque. The sheer desire to meet Bukayo Saka's cross outweighed the defender and produced the decisive moment.\n\nThe Arsenal winger was the main competition for Bellingham's player-of-the-match award on first-half evidence. With his team-mate roaming and Phil Foden drifting, Saka gave them the width needed and constantly beat his full-back.\n\nI don't know what happened in the second half but England were a different team. Southgate alluded to fitness issues perhaps tempting them to defend deeper. Possibly?\n\nThe way they surrendered the ascendency was worrying, as was the England boss' lack of reaction from the bench. I am not a Southgate basher by any means but criticism of his in-game management can't be defended, at times.\n\nIt was clear on the hour-mark that England had run out of steam, needed more legs in the middle and a better outlet out wide to stretch Serbia.\n\nConnor Gallagher came 10 minutes too late, as did Jarrod Bowen. Anthony Gordon should've been introduced too given how ineffective Foden became and how lop-sided their attack was.\n\nThe biggest concern for me in the group stages is England's left side. How do they get a better balance? Well, hopefully, Luke Shaw will be fit soon and that will certainly help, but it's worrying to rely on a half-cooked defender who hasn't played since February.\n\nFor the good of the team, Southgate either needs to compromise or drop one of his star attackers. On the evidence of the first half, I see no reason why Declan Rice, who was excellent, Bellingham and Foden can't play together. Particularly, against weaker opposition.\n\nIf Southgate is insistent that isn't for him then someone has to be sacrificed for the balance of the team. England have always looked at their best with runners beyond Harry Kane, think Raheem Sterling and Marcus Rashford at their best.\n\nThe captain was isolated and ineffectual, particularly second half, through little fault of his own. England would be a far better team, in my opinion, with Saka and Gordon in the team, on either flank.\n\nFoden has not produced the moments of magic we've seen regularly for Manchester City. Saka and Bellingham's contributions in an England shirt far outweigh his, unfortunately.\n\nIt would be a crying shame if someone as talented as Foden can't get in the England team. But it would be even worse to jeopardise the effectiveness of the team just to shoe-horn him in.\n\nEngland's defence stood up to the challenge, which was a big positive. Bellingham shrugged off any worries of burn-out or fatigue. But the same nagging doubts weren't eased on matchday one.\n\nNothing can be 'okay' anymore, as England found out on Sunday night.\n\nIn the lawless land of social media, you are either the greatest thing since sliced bread or the worst manager, player or team in the world, there is no middle ground.\n\nYou don't have to search very far to know what I mean. Phil Foden put out a tweet not long after the final whistle of a 1-0 win against Serbia, met largely by a barrage of abuse from nameless morons who should have been in bed.\n\nHe didn't play particularly well and there is definitely a wider debate to be had about his starting position in his England team, and whether he can have the same impact out wide without the guiding hand of a Bernardo Silva or a Kevin De Bruyne around him.\n\nBut judging by some of the comments you'd think his inclusion in the team was somehow controversial, and that he wasn't a generational talent comparable with anyone in this tournament.\n\nHas social media reduced concentration and intellect levels to the point where we can't consider one performance on its merits, and must polarise every single opinion lest we miss out on a few likes?\n\nFoden's performance was a five out of 10, I'd argue the same could be said about Kieran Trippier who played within himself on the left. That literally nothing was going down that side of the pitch for England reinforces those lopsided arguments that have been thrown at England, especially without Luke Shaw.\n\nI can understand the disappointment that the team became unnecessarily submissive in the second half and there were some poor choices in possession all over the pitch which meant they could not build attacks in the same way they did over the first half an hour.\n\nIt might just mean, however, that England are a good team finding their form, not a great one taking backward steps. And that's OK, it might still be enough to win them the tournament.\n\nNearly 15 million people tuned into England v Serbia at its peak - which is four million more than any other UK programme during 2024.\n\nAmazing numbers in this digital world and good ammunition for whoever sells the adverts for these major tournaments.\n\nI don't claim to have a firm grip on global branding but there are some weird company names claiming centre stage in Germany.\n\nI've already expressed my dislike for ITV's coverage giving blanket sponsorship to 'Visit Qatar' though I appreciate it is probably a UEFA tie-in. I am becoming increasingly frustrated at the BBC lobbing in trailers for iPlayer, though, regardless of how well Mark Pougatch builds up the new season of the Great British Sewing Bee.\n\nThe corporate sponsors have provided some head-scratching moments. The perimeter of the pitch often flashes up someone boasting to be the \"No1 Nev Maker\" - a title that can surely only be bestowed on Gary Neville's grandad.\n\nDavid Beckham pops up in random adverts for Alipay, giving little clue what they actually do, and something called Hisense proudly and ambiguously claims to be ranked \"Number Two Globally\". Well done to them.\n\nLidl's name is everywhere, as is a company called Atos, which according to Google specialises in hi-tech transactional services, unified communications, cloud, big data and cybersecurity services. Nope, me neither.\n\nThrow in the fact you can't turn on a laptop up to three hours before an England game without Paddy Power finding some way to offer you a novel way to fritter your money away, and it all leaves you feeling a bit icky.\n\nNot quite as bad, however, as the advert for Hellman's mayonnaise, clearly filmed well in advance of the Euros, which has among its stars Jack Grealish and Marcus Rashford. {"uri": "8181928765", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "12:59:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T12:59:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T12:59:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.football365.com/news/england-clamour-rankings-anthony-gordon-trent-foden", "title": "England: Anthony Gordon in for Trent as Newcastle man leads the Clamour rankings", "body": "England have won their opening game so who needs to be dropped? And who is the subject of the biggest Clamour to come in? We rank the top five...\n\n5) Adam Wharton\n\n'With all the caveats of - I'm not watching training, I've never seen him play a full 90, he plays higher up the pitch than I thought and I'VE NEVER PLAYED THE GAME, I'd like Adam Wharton in,' tweeted Max Rushden in that terrifically clever manner that protects him against accusations that his instincts are unfounded while still voicing those largely unfounded instincts.\n\nWharton would be higher up this list if he had played more than 16 Premier League games and more than 28 minutes of international football, but there is still a sizeable Clamour building for his inclusion at the expense of Trent Alexander-Arnold, who looks uncomfortable in midfield because he is not a midfielder. Which seems important.\n\nThe truth? There is no perfect solution to that midfield problem. And in the absence of a perfect solution, Gareth Southgate has opted for the best footballer - but not the best midfielder - available.\n\n4) Kobbie Mainoo\n\nA year younger than Wharton but with a whole 25 Premier League games (and one barnstorming FA Cup final display) under his belt, which is probably why he eventually came on for Jude Bellingham in the 'seeing it out' role. Rio Ferdinand has said he should have come on earlier, presumably instead of the energetic but absolutely not composed Conor Gallagher.\n\nThere will always be a greater Clamour for players from well-supported clubs and it does feel rather odd that England started a major tournament without a Manchester United player. He does have a significant advantage over Alexander-Arnold in that he is actually a midfielder. Which seems important.\n\nOh and he was excellent alongside Declan Rice v Belgium in March, when we wrote: 'Literally impossible to watch his interplay with Jude Bellingham and not get very giddy indeed.'\n\nMORE ON SERBIA v ENGLAND FROM F365:\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Jude Bellingham's England (just) beat Serbia: 16 Conclusions on an unnecessarily nervy opener\n\n\ud83d\udc49 England player ratings v Serbia: Bellingham runs the show, Kane quiet, Saka shows positive signs\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Harry Kane was 'static and lumbering' as he faces calls to be dropped by England\n\n3) Eberechi Eze\n\n\"I'm going to say and I'm going to make this statement as early as possible. We talked about early substitutions leading into the game, I tell you what I'd do, I'd bring Eze on now to attack instead of Foden. You ask for my opinion and I'll give you my solution after 29 minutes!\"\n\nStuart Pearce went very, very early but he was soon joined by many others who wanted the ineffective Phil Foden replaced by a player who had made such an impact on the left side against Bosnia and Herzegovina in a Euro 2024 warm-up match that he immediately cemented a place on the plane.\n\nThere was such a stark contrast between the impact of Bukayo Saka on the right and Foden on the left that it screams classic Clamour this week; that problematic left side has rich history in this particular narrative as Jack Grealish and James Maddison have both been regular beneficiaries. Eze does not quite have those 'We need a maverick!' vibes, which is why he is third and no higher on this list.\n\n2) Cole Palmer\n\nIt says something about the strength of England's other striker options that the main beneficiary of Kane largely being nothing more than a bystander against Serbia is Cole Palmer rather than Ollie Watkins or Ivan Toney.\n\nPalmer finished the season with more combined Premier League goals and assists than any other player so there was always going to be some consternation about him not even getting on the pitch v Serbia. He cannot replace Saka (and Jarrod Bowen's cameo put paid to any talk of him being the best back-up alternative there), has no history of playing on the left and Jude Bellingham is untouchable, so striker it is.\n\nFerdinand has called for \"someone like Cole Palmer who has got that bit of swagger and arrogance to say give me that ball\". He will not be the last.\n\n1) Anthony Gordon\n\nTrending on Monday morning because England lacked any kind of penetration down the left, and Gordon and his direct running is absolutely the antidote to Foden and the Pep-like inside-left interplay that nobody wants to see from England players (unless it goes well).\n\nProbably England's best left-sided winger but the question is whether Gareth Southgate wants a winger out there or just wants another of England's best footballers on the pitch. Gordon is about to become a cause celebre for all those who want Trent Alexander-Arnold dropped and Foden brought central alongside Jude Bellingham. However, he was unable to have the same influence on the game as he does for City, with Bellingham ultimately scoring the winner as England beat Serbia 1-0.\n\nAnd former Spain star Cesc Fabregas, who won the Euros twice in 2008 and 2012, suggested after the game that Foden needs \"impose himself\" on the game more like Bellingham did. Ferdinand agrees with Fabregas' assessment, claiming Foden is in a similar situation to Veron who was a \"ridiculous player\" but struggled at United because Roy Keane was \"much more dominant\".\n\nSpeaking on his FIVE podcast,\" Ferdinand said: \"Me, Micah [Richards] and Cesc done that game [for BBC ] the other day and Micah was saying how he felt sorry for Phil that and about how Southgate's not getting the best out of him.\n\n\"And then to be fair Cesc just put him away, just said, 'listen, no, no, no, it's down to Foden'. Foden's got to go out there and you're talking about body language, being demanding and authoritative with the way that you want the ball.\n\n\"Jude has got that in spades and I think if we're going to see the best out of Phil Foden, and I agree with Cesc, he's got to really go out there and try and dominate the pitch and dominate some of his teammates to give him the ball and be the first one to shout.\n\n\"But I've seen this before at Man United. We had Roy Keane who demanded the ball in the middle of the pitch. We signed a superstar in Juan Sebastian Veron. Ridiculous player, the streets will never forget this guy, that bandage under the knee...\n\n\"He was a playmaker that wanted to get the ball off all of the players and that's how he got his rhythm and play. But Roy Keane dominated because he was more animated, the characteristics that he had came out and was much more dominant.\n\n\"He was there before and dominated that area. And Sebastian Veron folded really and had to be sold and didn't really become a success at Man United. {"uri": "8182065124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "14:33:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T14:33:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T14:32:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.ladbible.com/news/sport/why-does-phil-foden-wear-number-47-shirt-795792-20240617", "title": "Heartwarming reason Phil Foden wears number 47 for Manchester City and he has it tattooed on neck", "body": "The number has a personal significance to the Premier League star\n\nThe heartwarming reason Phil Foden wears the number 47 jersey while playing for Manchester City has been revealed.\n\nThe England international, 24, has cemented himself as huge part of Pep Guardiola's Premier League winning side in the past couple of years, as well as being a key player for the Three Lions as they begin Euro 2024.\n\nDespite his rapidly rising profile, Foden still wears the number 47 when he plays for City - which is an unusual number for a senior member of the team.\n\nFoden was originally given the 47 shirt when he made his senior team debut back in 2017 and has stuck by the number since. In fact, he's even gone as far as getting the number tattooed onto his neck.\n\nAs an attacking midfielder would traditionally wear the legendary 10 jersey and you'd think that Foden would want to add his name to the long list of stars who've donned the famous shirt number.\n\nHowever Foden appears to have no intention of parting with his 47 shirt, even turning down an offer from departing player Sergio Ag\u00fcero when he left the club in 2021.\n\n\"I did think about it,\" the footballer said of Ag\u00fcero's offer in 2022. \"The ten shirt is such a big number in the club, but I just have a thing with 47.\n\n\"I'd like to create my own legacy and keep that number.\"\n\nThe number eventually went to his England teammate Jack Grealish.\n\nSo why is Foden so attached to the number? Turns out there's a very heartwarming reason.\n\nThe 47 jersey was a personal significance to the footballer, as 47 is the age that his granddad Ronnie passed away - meaning the number is a way for Foden to remember his late grandfather.\n\nIt's also been reported that Ronnie was an avid Manchester City fan, meaning that his grandson's decision to honour him at the club has an even more personal significance.\n\n\"Being a young player you don't have many options when it comes to what you can have on your shirt,\" Foden said in an interview with the Daily Mail.\n\n\"I had a few numbers sent to me and none of them really meant anything to me apart from that one, the 47.\"\n\nFoden then revealed that he'd consulted his dad other number, adding: \"I asked my dad if he would be happy if I wore that number. He said it would be amazing so I took the shirt number and I have loved it ever since.\n\n\"I have it tattooed on me now and it's a shirt I don't ever see changing. It's nice to make your own legacy. It's a strange number nobody else will go for so hopefully in years to come when I have finished, 47 at City will be remembered for Phil Foden.\"", "source": {"uri": "ladbible.com", "dataType": He was moved from his favoured No.10 position onto the left wing - with Jude Bellingham taking up the central playmaking role.\n\nAnd for Thursday's clash with Denmark, former England defender Brown wants to see the 24-year-old change his game so he can work with Bellingham - just as Rooney had to do in his partnership with Cristiano Ronaldo at Manchester United.\n\nSpeaking on Reach's new Euro Thrash podcast - which you can find on YouTube, Apple and Spotify - Brown said: \"We all know Foden has had a fantastic season but regardless of where he plays, he has to get into the game more.\n\n\"He will take a bit more responsibility because we all know how good he is on the ball, but he didn't quite get into the game. He has been used to playing in a different position for City this season, and it showed, but that is Jude Bellingham's position and you can't take Jude out of there.\n\n\"I'll give you a good example: Wayne Rooney, absolutely fantastic, wants the ball all the time, but when he was playing with Cristiano Ronaldo, when he was in his mood and you knew he was the guy, Wayne would start dropping back a little and start to assist him.\n\n\"Sometimes players have to be intelligent enough to do that. We know what a special player Foden can be, but Jude is special too, those are the two players that can produce in big games.\n\n\"Jude demands the ball and he just wants to get things going. {"uri": "8184970515", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:56:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:56:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:55:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/shearer-england-euro2024-southgate-bellingham-33060832", "title": "Alan Shearer demands two England changes in line-up prediction for Denmark clash", "body": "Alan Shearer wants two changes to the England side against Denmark - including a position change for Jude Bellingham.\n\nThe Three Lions opened up their Euro 2024 group campaign with a slender 1-0 victory against Serbia. Real Madrid midfielder Bellingham scored the winning goal in what was an uncomfortable evening.\n\nGareth Southgate's side now have the chance to all-but seal their spot in the knockout rounds should they beat Denmark. But Shearer wants to see tweaks to the England team ahead of that game.\n\nHe has demanded Southgate change both Bellingham and Phil Foden 's positions, with the addition of another wideman. As quoted by Betfair, the Newcastle icon said: \"I wouldn't call it a big concern, but the more pressing thing is what happened to Trent in midfield, I thought he did alright without being spectacular. Is Phil Foden going to continue to play on the left hand side?\n\n\"I don't think having a right footed left back in Trippier helps Foden, because every time you're getting the ball, you are receiving it on the inside. Those are the things I'd be looking at.\n\n\"The two talking points are who plays alongside Rice and who plays on that left side. Saka on the right in the first half was unplayable, he tied the two left sided players inside out, in the second half he didn't really have a kick because they came out and did much better.\n\n\"I would play Bellingham alongside Rice and Foden as the 10, which is where he wants to play. I don't think that would be a problem at all, you're playing Bellingham with Rice so you free up that left side for someone who can run in behind, whether that would be Eze or Gordon. That's what I would have done and that's what I'd do against Denmark.\"\n\nWhat team should England name vs Denmark? Share your thoughts in the comments below\n\nWhile Shearer has demanded some slight tweaks to the England line-up, he does not believe that Southgate will ring the changes against Denmark. He added: \"There's no risk in changing things, you've won the game, you look at the positives and you ask why things happened, how things happened, you look at the negatives and look at how you can improve.\n\n\"We've got a squad of 26 players, of which the vast majority would have no problem with going in the starting line up, it's great to have options. The options he has got, one on the left side and two in the middle of the park are phenomenal. It's not dangerous to change it up, it's dangerous to make six or seven changes which he won't, but he may make one or two.\"\n\nFollowing their clash with Denmark, England then round off their group stage against Slovenia. Why does Germany feel like a country unready to host Euro 2024?\n\nPhil Foden's relatively lack-lustre performance on Sunday against Serbia has left Mail Sport's football experts pondering Gareth Southgate's latest quandary: What to do with the Man City star?\n\nFoden is likely the most technically gifted player that England can call upon, and has had an unbelievable campaign with Man City once more, but he is still yet to bring his best to the national team.\n\nHe appeared ineffectual and frustrated in Gelsenkirchen, and with a huge depth of talent waiting quite literally in the wings, talk has turned to Foden's place in the side - should he be dropped? Should he start at No 10?\n\nAfter Jack Gaughan and Craig Hope discussed where Foden should play - the former claiming it would be 'sacrilege' to drop him, while the latter suggests moving him to No 10 and bringing in Anthony Gordon - Ian Ladyman describes leaving the forward out as 'a kneejerk reaction to end all kneejerk reactions'.\n\nMike Keegan then contends that the XI that faced Serbia was not England's best, and both he and Ladyman agree that Cole Palmer would come in for Trent Alexander-Arnold, with Bellingham dropping in alongside Declan Rice and Foden playing as a No 10.\n\nKeegan also predicts Foden will be named Player of the Tournament, before the discussion turns to whether Bellingham would be as effective alongside Rice, or whether his natural propensity to roam around the field could give England more problems.\n\nListen to It's All Kicking Off! on Spotify or Apple Podcasts. {"uri": "2024-06-395516552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:07:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:07:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T05:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/24398199.euro-2024-column-harry-kane-phil-foden-englands-choice/", "title": "Euro View: Who shares England's spotlight and can Phil Foden bounce back?", "body": "HOPEFULLY it isn't just the beer that is back to full strength when England face Denmark in Frankfurt this evening.\n\nQuite why fans thought they should steamroll through Serbia without breaking a sweat in Gelsenkirchen, I have no idea.\n\nThe warning signs were there, Gareth Southgate hasn't got a particularly balanced side, there are a few still finding their top fitness level and there are still question marks against Trent Alexander-Arnold as an international midfielder. So why such a negative reaction?\n\nOne positive, at least in my mind, is that all of the above can improve as time goes on in this competition. If you continue to carve out results while the progress is made, then there really shouldn't be any room for complaint.\n\nI want to see Phil Foden back to his best, I want to see England get him into the same sort of areas that Manchester City do, and with Denmark needing a positive result after their draw against Slovenia there is every reason to believe he will get some more space and freedom.\n\nI wanted to see Foden playing number 10, and after the season he had at club level for Southgate to say 'go and win the Euros for us'. You could say the same thing to Jude Bellingham from any of the midfield positions and he would still have a big impact.\n\nBut Foden can't get too down about it, and neither should we. He has ample class to find his way into tonight's game, provided he gets the right kind of support, and you only have to look back in history to see that central players can still affect major tournaments from wide positions - a la Mesut Ozil for Germany (2014), Andres Iniesta for Spain (2010) or Simone Perotta for Italy in 2006.\n\nCesc Fabregas made a good point the other night, talking about the mentality of players like Xavi or Iniesta, and how they wanted to take responsibility of the ball in the most pressured situations at top tournaments.\n\nWe talk about the pressure of the English press and supporters but it is no different in Spain, it is down to the individual.\n\nThe 'problematic left' was an English clich\u00e9 when I was growing up. There always seemed to be some furore about John Barnes not replicating his Liverpool form for his country - although knowing what disgusting abuse he took in some places I can understand why he might have had issues.\n\nThereafter we had a chain of underperforming successors that carried on right the way through the 'Golden Generation' until the game evolved tactically, and it became less of a stigma playing a right-footed player on the left.\n\nNobody bats an eyelid at Bukayo Saka playing out on the right. He was one of England's chief threats on Sunday night against Serbia in the first half before tiring, after which you have to give Jarrod Bowen some credit for the energy he showed as a replacement.\n\nIf Foden isn't working against Denmark then England could turn to Anthony Gordon for more direct running, Eberechi Eze for a bit of skill, or Cole Palmer for a bit more craft, but I'd like to see Southgate make these changes a little earlier.\n\nOverall, I am confident. If England can book their place in the next round and leave us with fewer question marks between here and the final game, then that is progress.\n\nIT must be a strange feeling for Harry Kane, not having the weight of 11 men, a whole club, or a nation on his shoulders.\n\nThe England captain has certainly carried his fair share of weight in the last six or seven years, looked upon for goals, for inspiration, for the right words after every victory and defeat.\n\nBut if there is something to be taken from the opening win against Serbia it is that England do have other talismans these days, it isn't all on Kane to produce a moment of magic.\n\nJude Bellingham is the obvious example. Much has been discussed about Phil Foden - but he is more than capable of being that man too - and Bukayo Saka lit the touchpaper so many times for Arsenal last season, but his star-power is overlooked a little for his country at times.\n\nKane touched the ball twice in the first half on Sunday evening, and that was during England's best spell. He had more involvement in the second half and was unlucky to have one header tipped on to the crossbar but by his sky-high standards it was a mediocre display.\n\nHe is, however, a player on whom you would bet your mortgage if it really mattered. His mentality is second to none and someone who commands respect from every single nation in this tournament.\n\nOpposing teams make plans to stop Harry Kane and if they are successful that might have been a serious problem. Nowadays, though, it feels like the more attention they pay to the number nine, the more space it offers to others.\n\nEngland are learning to share the spotlight, maybe it is their best way to get to where they want to be?\n\nI CAN remember trying to revise for my A Levels during Euro 96, a pointless task which is why I can now tell you more about Davor Suker, Karol Poborsky or Hristo Stoichkov than I can about fluvial dynamics or Schema Theory.\n\nTrying to study while you are also starring for your country? Well, that's just showing off.\n\nBarcelona's Lamine Yamal is managing to do just that for Spain, juggling studies with becoming the youngest-ever player at the Euros aged 16 and 338 days. And if he carries on the way he is going, that 17th birthday party is going to be a banger.\n\nIt is realistic to expect such a young player to continue playing the way he did against Croatia? Of course not. But it is a wonderful story that shows age is nothing but a number.\n\nTurkey's Arder Guler did the same thing, producing a brilliant goal against Georgia in Dortmund.\n\nA couple of years older but a Real Madrid talent who is no less exciting, he was a major influence in what must be the best game of the competition so far.\n\nThrow in elder statesman Jude Bellingham, 10 days shy of his 21st birthday, Germany's Jamal Musiala and Portugal's winning goal-scorer against the Czechs, Fransisco Conceicao, and this tournament has seen some brilliant performances from its youngest players already.\n\nI can't wait to see if Yamal and Spain can shine again when they take on Italy tonight, a game I fear might be a bit cagier than those we have watched in the opening round as neither will want a defeat on their record.\n\nItaly didn't convince me against Albania, so I think Spain have the edge in quality. But if any country can see out a draw and take it to the last game, it will be the Azzurri.", "source": {"uri": "theboltonnews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Bolton News"}, "authors": Who do you play in there?\n\n\"You could go for Conor Gallagher or Adam Wharton, there's a few options there.\n\n\"You could put Kobbie Mainoo in there, but I think that's a big step up for him. Trent gets caught on the ball too much.\n\n\"I said this before the tournament, it isn't rocket science, I've been a footballer and people know the game.\n\n\"When you play in midfield, you get caught on the ball if you're not playing in there week in week out.\n\n\"It's a completely different position to right back, the way you move, the way you see, the awareness you need to have and how you have to protect the ball in certain areas when you come under pressure - it is completely different.\"", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": None of them really meant anything to me apart from that one, the 47.\n\n\"That was the age my grandad was when he died. I was young when we lost him.\n\n\"I remember going to Wales with him and on a few other trips. My dad says he loved playing football with me.\n\n\"I asked my dad if he would be happy if I wore that number. He said it would be amazing, so I took the shirt number and I have loved it ever since.\"\n\nFoden explained how he subsequently got the number tattooed on his neck for the same reason, and added: \"It's a shirt I don't ever see changing.\n\n\"It's a strange number nobody else will go for, so hopefully in years to come when I have finished, 47 at City will be remembered for Phil Foden.\"\n\nThe City and England star also has another tribute to his grandfather - in the form of his middle name, Walter.\n\nSpeaking to CNN FC in January, he revealed: \"I don't think many people realised that was {"uri": "8187160917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:59:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:59:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:58:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.90min.com/england-best-starting-lineup-euro-2024-clash-denmark", "title": "Picking England's best starting lineup for Euro 2024 clash with Denmark", "body": "Picking the ENGLAND XI vs DENMARK! Mainoo and Gordon IN? Alexander-Arnold OUT? / 90min Football\n\nEngland kickstarted their Euro 2024 campaign with a win over Serbia, but it was a win which left fans with more questions than answers regarding Gareth Southgate's tactical set-up.\n\nSome fans called out Southgate's defensive set-up (particularly in the second half), others weren't happy with the Trent Alexander-Arnold midfield experiment, and others wondered why Phil Foden was so quiet on the left flank.\n\nSo how does Southgate address all of these issues?\n\nAhead of the clash with Denmark, 90min's esteemed team of writers and editors have addressed the situation and chosen their ideal XIs for the game.\n\nPicking Trent Alexander-Arnold for the\u00c2 first\u00c2 game was the right decision in my book, but it's clear there's dysfunctionality in England's midfield. Is there any value in adding more fuel to the fire at a major tournament? Probably not, so take the stress out of the situation and drop Jude Bellingham deeper and move Phil Foden centrally.\n\nThe benefit of doing that allows England to bring in a different kind of option, namely Anthony Gordon. Pace in behind, the ability to stretch a game and do something different down the left, that's what it feels like England need against Denmark. If we're really talking ideals, perhaps Alexander-Arnold would be pinging diagonals at right-back instead of Kyle Walker, but one step at a time.\n\nI'm only going with one change from the Denmark game. At this point, the Trent Alexander-Arnold midfield experiment is one I'm still not sure can succeed at a major international tournament, but England lacked creativity out wide so plugging him into his natural right-back role in place of Kyle Walker would at least mean there's a more forward-thinking option to support Bukayo Saka.\n\nAnthony Gordon's express pace would be more beneficial than Phil Foden wandering around out wide with no support from the defensive Kieran Trippier, so the Manchester City star should start centrally where he can effect the game with Jude Bellingham using his twists and turns in a deeper position while bombing into the box. It's one on one.\n\nI'm sticking with the team I picked for the opener against Serbia, in which\u00c2 I was the only member of the team to select Trent Alexander-Arnold in his actual position.\n\nI will die on this hill. Play him at right-back. Drop Kyle Walker.\n\nThere's not many changes for me, and we have the luxury of playing a team like Denmark next while we sit atop the group so we should be quite safe regardless. But we have\u00c2 to make a change\u00c2 on that left hand side, it just does not work.\n\nI'm bringing in Anthony Gordon to add something different on the left. His pace his outstanding and he deserves his chance. It's time we start using player's club performances to pick our squad, and in using that mentality I'm bringing Newcastle's x-factor star in.\u00c2\n\nOur defence is not perfect, and if Luke Shaw was fit then he'd demand a place. But for now it will do.\u00c2\n\nPhil Foden struggled to get time on the ball on Sunday and I think it makes sense to bring in Eberechi Eze at this point, to see what he can do.\n\nI thought Trent Alexander-Arnold played well against Serbia, but Gallagher proved himself to be a good burst of energy when he was subbed on, and I think he deserves to start as a result.\n\nEngland obviously started well against Serbia, but it descended into a backs to the wall job by the end because of a lack of control in the middle. Trent Alexander-Arnold divided opinion because he was fine on the ball but isn\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t a midfielder when it comes to shape and defending.\n\nEngland are screaming out for Kobbie Mainoo, who has already shown at club level he can handle himself despite his age and lack of experience. England need to be stamping their authority on games like this so their world class talent can actually perform. {"uri": "8186415379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:02:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:02:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:01:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/cprr8gdjn85o", "title": "Euro 2024: Should England start Phil Foden against Denmark?", "body": "Gareth Southgate's England squad selection for Euro 2024 received widespread approval for being bold and courageous - and yet he is still revisiting a debate stretching back two decades.\n\nIt is a conversation that returns to the era when England's then-manager Sven-Goran Eriksson failed to cash in what looked like a golden ticket stamped with the names of Steven Gerrard, Frank Lampard and Paul Scholes.\n\nEriksson's star-struck approach led him to pack his team with England's best individuals rather than shape a fully-functioning balanced side, a forced and flawed strategy that left the so-called 'Golden Generation' unfulfilled at international level while sweeping up major prizes regularly with their clubs.\n\nIt ended with a disillusioned Scholes, wasted on the left flank at Euro 2004 in Portugal, calling time early on his international career, a world-class operator with Manchester United marginalised by England.\n\nAnd now there are hints of old arguments being raked over once more as England continue their Euro 2024 campaign against Denmark in Frankfurt on Thursday.\n\nSouthgate is not at the Eriksson stage yet - indeed he may never reach it - but he will be aware of the growing volume of the discussion around Manchester City's Phil Foden, England's young superstar Jude Bellingham and the make-up of his midfield elsewhere.\n\nAll the indications backstage in Frankfurt suggested Southgate will keep faith with Foden in the mainly left flank role he filled against Serbia, with Liverpool's Trent Alexander-Arnold alongside Declan Rice in the centre.\n\nIt has not silenced the argument and the noise increased after Foden - the Footballer of the Year with 27 league goals as Manchester City secured a fourth successive title - cut a peripheral figure in {"uri": "8187515451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:08:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:08:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:07:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/sport/24401641.england-1-denmark-1-familiar-failings-hurt-england-southgate/", "title": "Desperate draw with Denmark shows why England boss Gareth Southgate needs to change", "body": "YOU don't have to win every game to triumph at a major tournament. At some stage, though, you have to start playing well. So, while England's draw with Denmark is hardly a disaster in terms of their prospects of qualifying for the knockout stage of the Euros given that they sit level at the top of their group with their final opponents, Slovenia, the manner of yet another bitterly-disappointing performance has well and truly set the alarm bells ringing.\n\nThis was England, rinse and repeat. Cautious, disjointed and with a number of potentially key players clearly playing out of position. The problems were all there in the opening game against Serbia, and they were even more apparent as England were fortunate to escape with a draw against the Danes.\n\nLeading through Harry Kane's early opener, England were outplayed for the best part of an hour as Denmark rallied, equalised through a long-range strike from Morten Hjulmand and then passed up a couple of decent second-half chances for a winner.\n\nEngland struck the post through Phil Foden, but Trent Alexander-Arnold was badly out-of-sorts again at the heart of midfield, Jude Bellingham was unable to hit the standards he scaled at the weekend and Gareth Southgate was left with a series of questions to answer, both in terms of his tactics and the general sense of conservatism he has indoctrinated into his squad. Why do England's players underperform so regularly with their national team? Increasingly, it is hard not to conclude that it must have a fair bit to do with the manager.\n\nThe pattern of yesterday's game was remarkably similar to Sunday's opener against Serbia, which is turn was similar to so many matches on Southgate's watch. England scored inside the opening 20 minutes, but then retreated into their shell, inviting their opponents to come onto them. At the weekend, Serbia lacked the attacking firepower to take advantage of England's cautious mindset. Here, Denmark were deservedly back level before the break.\n\nFor the second game in a row, there was no sign of the drop-off coming in the opening 20 minutes or so, with England starting positively as they looked to get onto the front foot.\n\nFoden curled an early effort over after turning neatly in the 18-yard box, and when England's opener arrived in the 18th minute, it came via the most reliable of sources.\n\nKyle Walker was the architect of the strike, bursting beyond a switched-off Victor Kristiansen to reach Bellingham's slide-rule pass. Kristiansen thought he had the situation covered, but the wing-back hadn't factored in Walker's pace, and while the Manchester City defender's cut-back took a couple of deflections, the ball dropped invitingly for Kane.\n\nEngland's skipper was criticised after only touching the ball on two occasions in the whole of the first half against Serbia, but he wasn't going to pass up this kind of opportunity, and sure enough, he calmly slotted home from the edge of the six-yard box.\n\nSo far, so promising. But England are never more vulnerable than when they have taken the lead, and sure enough, over the course of the next quarter-of-an hour, Southgate's players dropped deeper and deeper, Denmark's midfielders began to dominate possession, and an equaliser began to feel inevitable.\n\nIt might have arrived just after the half-hour mark had Marc Guehi not produced a perfectly-timed last-ditch challenge to deflect Jonas Wind's shot over the crossbar, but with the red tidal-wave continuing to sweep towards the England goal, parity was restored 11 minutes before the interval.\n\nIt was a sloppy goal for England to concede, with the move starting from their own throw-in. Kane conceded possession to Kristiansen, he shuffled the ball infield, and from 30 yards, Hjulmand found the bottom left-hand corner via the inside of the post. Jordan Pickford appeared to have been unsighted by the players in front of him, and should perhaps have got closer to the ball, but the quality of Hjulmand's strike was undeniable.\n\nPickford had to deal with another long-range strike before the break, saving from Tottenham's Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg, and while Foden shot straight at Kasper Schmeichel at the other end after slaloming down the middle of the pitch, the game had developed a familiar feel.\n\nEngland's midfield wasn't functioning effectively - for the second game in row, Trent Alexander-Arnold felt like a square peg in a round hole as he repeatedly gave the ball away - but Southgate stuck steadfastly to his guns, refusing to make a half-time alteration.\n\nWhen Alexander-Arnold conceded possession cheaply again at the start of the second half, his time was finally up, although the introduction of Conor Gallagher in his place felt like another somewhat conservative move. Yes, Adam Wharton is untried. But is there any point in taking the Crystal Palace midfielder to Germany if you're not going to use him?\n\nAt least Foden was showing signs of life in a much-improved display from the weekend, and while he might not quite be 'on fire', despite the song that has been ringing around Germany on repeat in the last week, he came within an inch or two of restoring England's lead just before the hour mark.\n\nDrifting infield from his position on the left, which definitely doesn't play to his strengths, Foden drilled a 25-yard effort against the base of the right-hand post. A couple of minutes later, with England starting to get some joy on the break, Bukayo Saka fired over after dribbling his way into the box.\n\nIt was still all very disjointed though, with passes going astray and a sense of panic appearing to set in. Declan Rice blamed the admittedly-dreadful state of the pitch when he put the ball out for a corner midway through the second half, but the incident was indicative of England's general unease.", {"uri": "8187590100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:11:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:11:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:10:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.football365.com/news/england-player-ratings-denmark-trent-enforces-southgate-out-kane-bellingham-struggle", "title": "England player ratings v Denmark: Trent enforces Southgate Out clamour as Kane, Bellingham struggle", "body": "Gareth Southgate's failed Trent Alexander-Arnold experiment could be a massive contributing factor to England's imminent Euro 2024 exit. That was sh*t...\n\nJordan Pickford\n\nEngland's No.1 had a couple of nervy moments as he flapped at a cross and was beaten to the ball by Christian Eriksen when off his line. But for the goal, there was nothing more that Pickford could do as Morten Hjlulmand's sublime strike from range bounced off the inside of the post and into the net.\n\nThe players in front of Pickford were fortunate that their endless number of lapses in possession did not lead to more clean-cut chances in front of goal, as most of Denmark's on-target attempts went straight at the 'keeper. One of England's better performers, but that's really not saying much.\n\nKyle Walker\n\nOne of barely a handful of good moments from England's perspective came via Walker's advancing runs. He made a loose pass from Jude Bellingham look somewhat decent as he caught Victor Kristensen napping to nip the ball away from the Denmark man to play in Harry Kane for his goal.\n\nJohn Stones\n\nDecent but not sparkling. Looks a far cry from the player he is when at his roaming best in his hybrid role for Man City. One of many cases of an immense talent not being given the license to shine by the overly defensive-minded manager in the dugout.\n\nMarc Guehi\n\nEngland's best player. He did a great job of handling Manchester United's Rasmus Hojlund, whose inexperience and rawness was just as evident for Denmark as it was at Old Trafford for much of his debut season.\n\nGuehi did not have it all his way and had to make a brilliant recovery block to prevent a huge chance after being dispossessed in a dangerous area. But he did so admirably and was one player who stepped up when most others went missing.\n\nOne of the main talking points heading into this tournament surrounded Guehi being England's weak link. But his first two appearances suggest he's the opposite, with Gareth Southgate having far more serious problems which require immediate attention if his side are to reach the latter stages of Euro 2024.\n\nKieran Trippier\n\nEven in an unnatural position, he's rarely left wanting when defending in an England shirt. He's currently doing a job for Southgate and is rightly pushing forward and hogging the flank when Foden drops deep, but does not offer a threat and the Three Lions desperately need Shaw back to full fitness if this system is to have any hope of working later in the tournament.\n\nMORE ON ENGLAND FROM F365...\n\n\ud83d\udc49 'Lost on the pitch', 'one good ball', 'didn't work' - 10 pundit takes on Trent Alexander-Arnold\n\n\ud83d\udc49 France, Belgium booted out, Modric embarrassing and England win - what Euro 2024 shirt numbers say\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Ranking England's 15 benchwarmers on their chances of gatecrashing Gareth Southgate's first XI\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold\n\nDid nothing to justify Southgate's insistence on playing the Liverpool right-back in midfield. An awful pitch did not help his renowned passing range but he resembles a deer in the headlights in this unfamiliar position and is far from assured with any of his work. He was dragged off after 53 minutes and the change should have happened earlier.\n\nHis ineffective display should surely end a Southgate experiment doomed to fail from the get-go and has exposed the manager's tactical frailties. His baffling use of Alexander-Arnold will contribute to his final chapter as England's boss being a downer.\n\nDeclan Rice\n\nSimilar to Stones, Rice resembles a footballer playing with shackles around his ankles in this system after he clearly showed during the Premier League run-in that his best position is as a No.8.\n\nBut Southgate has never had trust in his defence and as long as he's England's manager (which thankfully, will not be for much longer), Rice will be held back in this current role.\n\nSaying that, like the rest of his England team-mates, Rice was pretty hopeless in possession and the scoreline would have been ugly were they playing a more clinical opponent.\n\nBukayo Saka\n\nHis first-half performance against Serbia was the Arsenal winger at his scintillating best, but he faded in that game after being taken off and only impressed in flashes.\n\nHe was probably a 6/10 while others were 4/10 or worse, but Saka does not seem to be fully recovered from his injury issues as he's showing restraint when running at defenders and giving his opponents an easier ride than they are used to.\n\nJude Bellingham\n\nThe Real Madrid sensation pretty much beat Serbia single-handedly in England's opening game, but the imperious 20-year-old slipped to the same level as his underperforming teammates as he let the game pass him by without making much of an impact.\n\nDid not come close to taking the game by the scruff of the neck as he did against Serbia and was pretty subdued throughout. It's been a gruelling season for the youngster and there were signs this evening of this campaign catching up with him.\n\nREAD: England bound for Euro 2024 glory thanks to druids and despite doom-mongers\n\nPhil Foden\n\nThe clamour for Newcastle United's Anthony Gordon to start on the left enhanced after Foden failed to get into the Serbia game.\n\nThe Manchester City standout was better this evening, but all of his good moments came through the centre of the pitch. It's almost as if he should just be played there. If only his manager cottoned onto that way of thinking...\n\nCame close when he struck the post from range in the 55th minute and in an ideal world, he'd start as a No.10 with Bellingham deeper alongside Rice, while Gordon/Eberechi Eze can be used on the left.\n\nHis emergence as England's Erling Haaland sparked backlash for some reason, but he showed why his work needs to be focused in the 18-yard box when he scored with his first chance to break the deadlock in a typically clinical fashion.\n\nBut signs of Kane reverting to type were clear from kick-off as he had more touches in the opening couple of minutes than he did in the whole first half against Serbia while dropping deep. This continued as the pressure immediately built on England after going in front.\n\nA frustrating theme of England in major tournaments is they drop back as soon as they take the lead and Kane's insistence on getting involved in midfield *once again* ensured they had no out ball when in trouble.\n\nAnd Kane contributed to Denmark's equaliser as an empty-headed pass - to God knows - from on the edge of England's box found Morten Hjlulmand, who let rip from range for a deserved leveller.\n\nConor Gallager (on 53rd min)\n\nHis first act saw him booked for a late foul after leading a solo press and got no better after as the one-dimensional terrier and favourite of Southgate did his case to replace Alexander-Arnold in the starting XI no good at all.\n\nEberechi Eze (on 68th min)\n\nWon a couple of fouls in the attacking half, but was unable to alter the course of the game as England's woefulness continued after Southgate's bold triple change with 20 minutes to go.\n\nOllie Watkins (on 68th min)\n\nSouthgate's uncharacteristically bold roll of the dice in the latter stages saw Kane, Foden and Saka replaced.\n\nThis switch reeks of a desperate manager hoping his increasingly frustrated critics would gloss over his negative ineptness and concentrate on him having a go in the latter moments with these changes. Unfortunately, he has no such luck with #SouthgateOut quickly trending on social media after full-time.\n\nOf the three players to come on at this point, Watkins was the most effective as a trademark in-behind run from a pass by Bellingham and his subsequent shot forced Schmeichel into a decent save. A positive sign and evidence he is a useful alternative option when Kane up front on his own is not working.\n\nJarrod Bowen (on 68th min)\n\nThe West Ham star really impressed after replacing Saka against Serbia as he further established himself as Southgate's go-to right winger if the Arsenal man gets injured.
